loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Hello world! Meet Teresa, a mother of three from Eldoret, a remote town in the Rift valley province of Kenya. She has spent the past seven years of her life farming. She sells eggs, milk, and vegetables produced on her farm. She also engages in personal business to make ends meet. T

eresa is a go-getter and has a great desire to succeed in life. Of all the activities she involves herself in, poultry farming is closest to her heart. She enjoys waking up every morning to go and feed her birds. She is so close with her animals that she has nicknamed one of them “Kipara,” meaning no feathers on the head. 

Teresa wants to take full advantage of poultry farming as a profitable business venture. She would like to expand her poultry business, but the biggest challenge she faces is lack of capital. She is requesting a loan of 30,000 KES which she will use to buy additional poultry. With this loan, Teresa will be able to expand the poultry section on her farm. This will generate enough income to repay the loan, and she will also be able to save extra money. 

Teresa is very concerned about her child’s education, so profits from farming will go to pay for his school fees. Teresa dreams of a secure future for her children. Teresa awaits your kindness.

loans.use: buy poultry

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to start horticulture farming

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Hello, world! Meet Emily, a farmer from Tulwet. Tulwet is a remote area in Eldoret, Kenya, an area known for producing the best marathon runners, who have broken world records.

This mother of two is not interested in any farming activity other than dairy, which she started doing three year ago and has never looked back. She loves it! Her main source of income is milk. Emily is very appreciative of the fact that milk prices in the region are high. This enables her to enjoy a good profit margin and expand her operations. She has named her favorite dairy cow "Tukaa". Milking and feeding her cow is her hobby.

Emily is seeking a loan to purchase an additional dairy cow in order to boost milk production to increase sales volume. She believes the key to increased milk production is proper health. A dairy cow needs roughage and protein in her diet to be healthy.

Emily will use the additional income she will make to further her children’s education.

loans.use: to buy an additional dairy cow.

loans.name: Ashraf

texts.en:
Ashraf is 24 years old, single  and a Palestinian refugee. He graduated three years ago and got a job in a hospital's X-ray department in August 2011.
Ashraf is a hard-working man with a very good reputation in his region. He is the sole earner of his family, responsible for three members. Ashraf's home is far from the hospital he works in, and most of the time he has night and overnight shifts which creates a major transportation problem for him. That's  why he is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua, to buy a car to provide transportation to work.
He hopes that in the future, he can establish a business selling mobile phones and improve his family's living conditions.

loans.use: To buy a car to provide transportation to work

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
Zainab is a 45-year-old married mother of three children. Due to the low income from her husband, she started six years ago baking special bread to cover the needs and expenses of her family.
Zainab is an ambitious woman and a sacrificing mother who is trying hard to develop her business. She is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to buya  kneader and paste cutter to facilitate her business and provide her customers with better and quicker service.
Zainab hopes to expand her business more in the future to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy a kneader and paste cutter

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy plating for earrings, chains and bracelets.

loans.name: Wishnoe

texts.en:
Wishnoe is feeling very blessed to know that so many Kiva lenders helped him realize his dream.
He repaid his loan fully and is thankful to Kiva lenders.
With the profits, he has started building his own house. He needs more money to continue building and that's why he wants to continue rice cultivation so he can use the profits for building his house.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and pesticides.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a married man. He has two children who are three and five years old. He describes himself as optimistic. He operates a photography business. He has been involved in this business for six years. His business is located in a busy place. He says his biggest business challenge is lack of capital. 

Charles will use the KES 40,000 loan to buy more stock of photography accessories. His business goal is to own a photo studio within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will have better living standards. This is his second loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. His previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of photography accessories

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
El Grupo De Crédito San Vicente se reúne cada quince días en la parroquia Picoaza de la ciudad de Portoviejo. Lugar conocido por ser una zona muy comercial, por sus fiestas tradicionales de San Pedro y San Pablo y por la alegría de su gente.
La señora Carmen tiene  66 años de edad, hace varios años s esposos falleció pero de esa relación tiene 5 hijos los cuales ya son mayores de edad, una hija aun viven con ella a pesar de que está casada vive con su familia.
Doña Carmen con la intención de ganar algo por su cuenta y con esto poder salir adelante en el hogar se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo, su forma de  venta es puerta a puerta, sale dos o tres veces por semana pero también vende en su  casa donde tiene un pequeño local y allí vende todos los días, ella deja a crédito y cobra cada quince días. Tiene más de 11 años que se dedica a esta actividad con la cual sale adelante sin ayuda de nadie.
Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar en ropa en especial de temporada playera. Es socia fundadora del Grupo De Crédito y le gusta por la ayuda que le brindan los créditos. Sus sueños es tener un buen local.
texts.en:
The San Vicente communal bank group meets every two weeks in the Picoaza parish in the city of Portoviejo. This is a place known as a very commercial zone, for its traditional festivals of San Pedro and San Pablo, and for the happiness of its people.

Camen is 66 years old. Several years ago, her husband died, but from this relationship she has 5 children who are adults, a daughter still lives with her despite being married, she lives with her family.

Carmen, with the intention of earning something on her own account, and with this to be able to get ahead in the household, works selling all sorts of clothing. She method of sales is door-to-door, she goes out two or three times a week but she also sells in her house where she has a small retail space and there she sells every day. She leaves items on credit and collects every two weeks. She has more than 11 years doing this work, with which she gets ahead without the help of anyone.

This loan will be used to purchase clothing, especially in the t-shirt season. She is a founding member of the communal bank group and she likes it for the help that the loans offer her. Her dream is to have a good retail space.

loans.use: to purchase clothing

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is a 50-year-old woman married to Peter, blessed with six children, the youngest is 14 years.

Veronica is a tailor, a business she has run for the last 13 years, and earns a monthly income of 30,000 KES.

Veronica requested a 3rd loan with VisionFund Kenya of  30,000 KES which she will use to buy dressmaking materials especially as we approach the festive season.

Her hopes and dreams for the future is to improve the standards of living of her family.

loans.use: to buy dressmaking materials.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more stock of shoes

loans.name: Stanslaus

texts.en:
Stanslaus is 45 years old and lives in the town of Nakaloke in the Mbale region of Uganda. He is married and has five children, with two of them currently in school. For the past seven years, Stanslaus has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells essential items such as sugar, rice, beans, and maize flour.

To help expand his business, Stanslaus has requested a loan of 4,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more essential items for sale, and will help Stanslaus to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children in better schools. Stanslaus hopes that in the future, he will be able to add more stock to the business.

Stanslaus is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Stanslaus who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more essential items for sale.

loans.name: Boniface

texts.en:
Boniface is 55 years old and married with nine children, ages 7 to 30 . Five children go to school. He has been farming for 35 years. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to buy more fertilizer for maize. The profits from the business will be used to buy food for his family.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer for maize.

loans.name: Pertaap

texts.en:
Pertaap once again thanks Kiva lenders for helping him with his rice cultivation. With the profits resulting from the loan, he has renovated his house. He also was able to save money for the future.

Pertaap wants to continue rice production and needs another loan to purchase diesel and other inputs for his rice cultivation.

loans.use: To buy diesel

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary is a married woman. She has four children. She describes herself as good. She operates a retail business where she sells chicken. She has been involved in this business for 10 years. Her business is located in a good area, and her primary customers are hotels. 

Rosemary says her biggest business challenge is lack of finances. She will use the KES 98,000 loan to buy more stock of chickens and improve on the poultry housing. She hopes that in the future, she will be financially stable. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: buy more stock of chickens and improve on the poultry housing

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Meet Elizabeth from Eldoret Kenya, a woman from a community not known for farming but she is earning a living through agriculture. She is happily married, and together with her husband is blessed with four lovely children. For the past 20 years, she has been practicing mixed farming, and, because of the experience she has, she commands a lot of respect from fellow farmers and is regarded as a mentor. Income from selling milk, eggs, and maize has allowed her to earn a decent income. Elizabeth passionately loves dairy farming, and animals on her farm have been given names such as Lelmet. Milking and feeding Lelmet (the name of her cow) makes her very proud.

By selling milk, she has had good returns, and the demand for milk has been expanding. Through extensive use of her mobile phone, she receives orders from customers and then sends her customers a text message when the milk is ready for collection. Demand has been overwhelming, and she needs an extra breed of cow to satisfy fully the demand. She is requesting a loan to buy a quality dairy cow. Elizabeth does not intend to buy just an ordinary cow; she wants to buy a distinct breed that is easy to manage and has a natural ability to produce rich, creamy milk. The dairy cow will produce between 15-20 liters of milk a day. The increased milk production will translate into more income, and Elizabeth will be able to improve her living conditions and secure the future of her children going to school.

loans.use: to buy a quality dairy cow.

loans.name: Gituamba Abc Women Group

texts.en:
Mary, at left in the photo, is 32 years old, married and a mother of three children. She is a member of Gitumba ABC Women Group which joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa to benefit from training on enterprise and financial management. She does small-scale farming where she practices both dairy and vegetable farming. She also operates a business selling potatoes and kale in the local market. She is borrowing money from Kiva to boost her potato-selling business by buying more stock so that she can meet customers' rising demand.  Mary looks forward to improved income to be in a position to support her children’s education. 
Mary is very thankful to Kiva and all their lenders and promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: To buy more potatoes to satisfy customers' rising demand

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.en:
This is Jacinta, who is 54 years old, married and a mother of four children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa to benefit from the training on enterprise management. She does small-scale farming where she raises vegetables and practices dairy farming. She operates a curio shop selling traditional jewels. She is borrowing money to boost her curio shop business so that she can meet her customers' demand. She hopes to get more profits from the business. She plans to use the anticipated income to offer better education to her children and basic needs for the family such as food and clothing. 
Jacinta is happy for Kiva and their lenders and promises to repay the loan promptly

loans.use: To buy more jewels for the curio shop business to help meet customers' rising demand.

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en:
Hussein is a 25-year-old single man who has sold clothes for two years to help meet the needs and expenses of his family.

Hussein is an ambitious, hard working man who is trying to develop his business. He is acquiring a YOUTH loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to increase his business merchandise with a new collection of winter clothes for the Christmas season. This loan will help Hussein satisfy his customers' needs, increase his income, and improve his living conditions.

loans.use: to increase his merchandise with a new collection of winter clothes for the Christmas season.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy mineral fertilizers and fuel in order to plant her crops

loans.name: Margarita Annabel

texts.es:
El Grupo De Crédito San Vicente se reúne cada quince días en la parroquia Picoaza de la ciudad de Portoviejo. Lugar conocido por ser una zona muy comercial, por sus fiestas tradicionales de San Pedro y San Pablo y por la alegría de su gente.
 La señora Margarita tiene 37 años de edad, está divorciada y de esta relación tienen tres hijos de 19 y 6 años y el menor un bebé de 10 meses de edad,  uno  estudia en escuela.
Doña Margarita es una mujer que le toca trabajar  y así ganar sus propios ingresos para salir adelante junto a sus hijos, ella se dedica al comercio, vende ropa de todo tipo y  su forma de  venta es puerta a puerta, ella sale tres veces por semana unas tres horas por día pero también vende en su  casa hasta donde llegan sus clientes cuando lleva mercadería nueva, la mayor parte de su mercadería siempre es para entregar ya que los clientes cuando sabe que va a viajar le encargan a su gusto. Tiene más de 15 años que se dedica a esta actividad con la cual se gana la vida. 
Este crédito es para comprar camisetas, blusas, pantalones, entre otras prendas que ella vende. Lleva 8 años en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta porque los créditos le ayudan mucho. Sus sueños son que nunca le falte nada a sus hijos.
texts.en:
The credit group San Vicente meets every 15 days in Picoaza parish in the city of Portoviejo. It's known for being a very commercial area, for the traditional fiestas of San Pedro and San Pablo, and for the happiness of its people. 

Señora Margarita is 37 years old and divorced. From this relationship she has two children, aged 19 and 6, and a baby of ten months. One of her children studies in school.  

Doña Margarita is a woman who has to work in order to earn her own money and ensure that she can make progress together with her children. She sells all types of clothes door-to-door, going out three times a week for about three hours a day. She also sells clothes from her house, where customers come when she has new stock. She does most of her business door-to-door, however, as her customers, knowing when she will go out, place orders with her so that she can deliver the clothes to their homes. She has more than 15 years experience in this field and it is how she makes a living.  

She is asking for this loan in order to buy T-shirts, blouses and trousers, among other items of clothing, that she will sell. She has been a part of the credit group San Vicente for 8 years and she likes being a member because the loans help her a lot. Her dream is to make sure that her children never want for anything.

loans.use: to buy T-shirts, blouses, trousers and other items of clothing.

loans.name: Dancan

texts.en:
Dancan is a single man. He describes himself as being determined. 

Dancan operates a transport business where he transports customers using his motorcycle. He has been involved in this business for three years. His primary customers are of all types. He describes his biggest business challenge to be inadequate finances. 

He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy a car-washing machine to enable him to start a car-washing business. His business goal is to own a tuk tuk within five years. 

This is Dancan's first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy a car-washing machine to enable him to start a car-washing business.

loans.name: Winnie

texts.en:
While many young people in Africa dream of getting well-paying jobs, Winnie, from the Eldoret area of Kenya, left her “peanuts” paying job to become a full-time smallholder farmer. She decided that she would be independent and contribute to her community by practicing mixed farming.

Winnie is married and blessed with one child who she refers to as “my heart beat.” Her primary sources of income are milk selling, poultry farming, and some personal business that she does to supplement her meager income. Deciding to practice poultry farming for Winnie was not difficult. “I was brought up with chickens raised by my grandfather and grandmother,” Winnie said. “It is in my blood.”

For the past two years, Winnie has been earning a decent income from poultry farming. However, the demand is overwhelming, and she wants to increase her poultry, but the biggest challenge is the lack of funds. She is seeking a loan to purchase additional poultry.

Poultry farming has become one of the most important aspects of agriculture in Kenya because it creates business opportunity for entrepreneurs, and it’s a kind of business that can never dry up. Poultry farming is a less strenuous activity that is profitable. Many poultry farmers find a sense of fulfillment having hens all over their homestead. The hens lay eggs that can be consumed or sold. If taken seriously, poultry farming has the potential of being a big business because the demand for poultry products is always high.

With your loan, Winnie is going to make more income that will enable her to take care of her family's expenses. As the times keep getting harder, Winnie is doing all she can do to ensure that her family's basic needs are met.

loans.use: to buy poultry.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a married woman. She has three children. She describes herself as being honest. 

She operates a farm where she grows tea. She has been involved in this business for ten years. Her business is located in a strategic place. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate finances. 

Rose will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy farm inputs. Her business goal is to expand her business within five years. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs.

loans.name: Jean Baptiste

texts.en:
Jean Baptiste is a 48-year-old married man with 5 children  between 5 and 18 years old; all attend school. He has farmed for 22 years. He will use the loan to buy fertilizer. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for his children and buy food for his family.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizer.

loans.name: Bukurije

texts.en: Bukurije has been photographed with her husband, Halit. They request this loan to prepare about 9 dynym agricultural land for planting wheat.

loans.use: to prepare the land for planting wheat.

loans.name: Sajida

texts.en:
Sajida is a 37-year-old married woman. She has been selling spices which are used in cooking food for many years. She purchases spices in bulk at wholesale rates, and then sells them in packs of different sizes. She has become famous by providing high quality spices in her community and earns enough to support her family. 

Sajida is a responsible mother of three children and needs to earn more to bear the daily expenditures of her family members. For this reason, she requested a loan of 55,000 PKR to buy a stock of salt, red chilies, black pepper and turmeric in large quantities to increase her sales. She is hopeful that increase in business will help her in generating more cash.

loans.use: to buy a stock of salt, red chilies, black pepper and turmeric in large quantities to increase her sales

loans.name: Mutwalib

texts.en:
Mutwalib is 56 years old and lives in the town of Mbale in the Mbale region of Uganda. He is married and has 5 children. For the past 12 years, Mutwalib has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells essential items like sugar, salt and water . 

Mutwalib has requested 3,000,000  UGX from BRAC Uganda to purchase essential items, and will help Mutwalib to generate greater profits,  take care of his family's basic needs, and increase his stock. Mutwalib hopes that in the future he will be able to develop his plot of land. 

Mutwalib is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Mutwalib who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase  sugar, salt, and water.

loans.name: Latifu

texts.en:
Latifu is 31 years old and lives in the town of Mbale in the Mbale region of Uganda. He is married and has 2 children. For the past 6 years, Latifu has been working hard to manage his retail shop to sell sugar, salt and water . 

Latifu has requested 2,500,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase grocery items, and will help Latifu to generate greater profits and increase his business. Latiifu hopes that in the future he will be able to build rental houses. 

Latiifu is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Latifu who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, salt, and water.

loans.name: Sanavar

texts.ru: Санавар 58 лет, вдова, воспитала 3 детей. У нее высшее образование, до пенсии работала в школе учителем английского языка, в качестве источника дохода для семьи Санавар в начале этого года начала заниматься торговлей детскими игрушками. Начатый со стартовой суммы в 50,000 сом (KGS) бизнес на сегодня приносит около 15,000 сом (KGS) в месяц. Этих средств не хватает на достойную жизнь, содержание семьи и помощь детям и внукам. В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Санавар обратилась в Банк «Бай – Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS) на покупку игрушек, так как к предстоящим праздникам на них будет большой спрос, часть средств будет потрачена на покупку скота для младшей дочери. Доходы от кредита Санавар планирует вложить в дальнейшее развитие ее бизнеса, чтобы накопить средства на обучение внучки.
texts.en: Sanavar is 58 years old, a widow and raised 3 children. She has a college education and worked as an English-language teacher at a school until her retirement. To provide a source of income for her family, Sanavar got involved in selling children's toys at the beginning of this year. The business started with an initial sum of 50,000 som (KGS), today yields about 15,000 som (KGS) per month. This money is not enough for a decent life, supporting the family and helping her children and grandchildren. In order to further develop her business, Sanavar requested a loan in the amount of 50,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum" Bank to buy toys in anticipation of the high demand for toys with the upcoming holidays and livestock for her younger daughter. Sanavar is planning to invest the earnings from the loan into further developing her business in order to save money for her granddaughter's education.

loans.use: to buy toys in anticipation of the high demand for toys with the upcoming holidays and livestock for her younger daughter

loans.name: Redhwan

texts.en:
Redhwan is an old man who lives in Sana'a, Yemen with his big  family in their own small house.  

He spent 30 years of his life working as a simple employee  before he  retired with a pension. It is very difficult for a retired man to meet the demands of his family, especially if none of them is employed. After he  retired, he found himself incapable of providing the same living standards for his family. This feeling annoyed him. 

One of his children has graduated from university but still depends of him for his pocket money because he couldn’t find any work. Redhwan didn’t like this situation and decided to find an income source for his son. He believes that the best thing he can do is to purchase a taxi for his son. This taxi will cover the expenses of the son and help him to save money. The only problem that faces Redhwan is the capital to buy the taxi, so he has applied for 1,300,000 YER from Al-Amal Microfinance Bank.

Redhwan looks forward to purchasing another taxi and renting it.

loans.use: to buy a taxi for his son.

loans.name: Ishaku

texts.en: Ishaku is a maize farmer from Makera village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Ishaku would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Ishaku can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Ishaku, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to purchase storage for his crops.

loans.name: Audi

texts.en: Audi is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Audi joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Abigel, Amos and Faruk.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Audi would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Audi can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Audi  spoke of his  ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: to purchase storage for his crops.

loans.name: Hauwa Yusuf

texts.en:
Hauwa Yusuf is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona Farmers Organization. Hauwa Yusuf joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her children: Najib, Zayyad and Jabir.  Before she became a Babban Gona member, Hauwa Yusuf would have had to sell her maize for low prices, soon after harvest, to cater to her immediate cash needs, such as food and clothing. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Hauwa Yusuf can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later, for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Hauwa Yusuf spoke of her ambition to use the additional income to educate her children, eventually hoping to ensure her children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to pay for school fees and uniforms, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Alicia Monserrate

texts.es:
El Grupo De Crédito San Vicente se reúne cada quince días en la parroquia Picoaza de la ciudad de Portoviejo. Lugar conocido por ser una zona muy comercial, por sus fiestas tradicionales de San Pedro y San Pablo y por la alegría de su gente.
Aquí vive la señora Alicia, tiene 36 años  de edad, es madre soltera de una  niña de 13 años de edad la misma que estudian en colegio. Ella vive en la casa de sus padres. 
Doña Alicia trabaja en una escuela de la localidad como maestra por contrato, pero allí mismo ella en sociedad con su padre  son los encargados del bar de la escuela donde venden alimentos que ella prepara de la manera más saludables para que los niños tengan muy buena alimentación, ellos varían el menú todos los días para no cansar a los niños. También en su casa se dedica a la venta de tarjetas y recargas telefónicas. Lleva 7 años con su negocio el cual le permite sacar adelante a su hija.
Este crédito lo va  a emplear para comprar víveres necesarios para preparar los alimentos, tarjetas y recargas telefónicas. Lleva 10 años en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta porque gracias a  los créditos ella empezó su negocio. Sus sueños son darles lo mejor a su hija.
texts.en:
The San Vicente Credit Group meets every fifteen days in Picoaza parish of the city of Portoviejo. This is a place known for its trade, traditional San Pedro and San Pablo festivals, and happy inhabitants. Alicia lives here. She is 36 years old, and is a single mother to her 13-year-old daughter, who studies at secondary school. Alicia lives with her parents. 

Alicia works in a local school as a contract teacher. Along with her father, she is also in charge of the snack bar at the school, which sells healthy food which she prepares so that the children are fed well. They vary the types of food they offer every day so that the children don't grow tired of it. At home, she also works selling phone cards and credit. She has seven years experience in this business and it helps her to support her daughter.

She will use this loan to buy the supplies she needs to prepare the food for the snack bar, as well as phone cards and credit. She has been a member of the Credit Group for ten years. She likes the group because, thanks to the loans she received, she was able to set up her business. Her dream is to offer her daughter the best of everything.

loans.use: to buy supplies, phone cards and credit.

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline is a married woman. She has three children, with ages ranging from five years to ten years. 

She operates a beauty salon where she offers beauty services. She has been involved in this business for ten years. Her primary customers are ladies. 

Pauline will use the KES 30,000 loan to buy more stocks of beauty products to use in the salon. She hopes that, in the future, she will own a big boutique. She will use the anticipated profits to open another beauty salon.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of beauty products.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is a married man. He has five children. He describes himself as being a risk-taker. 

He operates a retail business where he sells animal feed. He has been involved in this business for 15 years. His business is located in an agricultural area with potential and his primary customers are farmers. He describes his biggest business challenge to be inadequate finances. 

Patrick will use the KES 50,000 loan to buy more stocks of animal feed. His business goal is to expand his business within five years. He hopes that he will have a bright future. 

This is Patrick's fifth loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. His previous loan was successfully repaid.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of animal feed.

loans.name: Maria  Ana

texts.en:
Maria Ana is 39 years old and a resident of Coron, Palawan, Philippines. She is married to Edelberto, and they have 3 children, of which 2 are in high school and 1 is in elementary school. She manages her household while operating her business. She works hard to augment their income to support  their daily household needs and to send their children to school. 

Maria Ana operates a general store. In the Philippines, a general store is basically a small convenience store that sells fresh, dry, and packaged commodities directly to consumers. Almost all products are essential household items and food. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns income by buying supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum net income of 1000 PHP a day. 

To help her continue operations of her general store, she is requesting a 20,000 PHP loan. She will use the loan to buy sacks of rice, charcoal, soda, and other grocery items. She is positive that the loan will boost her income as she expands her business. Maria Ana hopes to maintain and grow her business so she can uplift the lives of her family. She strives hard to give her children the best education possible and prays for a quiet and happy life. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week at which time she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. She is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given her. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for  rice, charcoal, soda, and other grocery items to sell.

loans.name: Florije

texts.en:
Florije requests 150,000 ALL to repair the damaged stable roof.

Florije is a mother of two children and raises dairy cows and baby calves and crows wheat, beans, and fodder.  In addition to the cash she makes from the rural activity, she and her husband  receive retirement pensions; they have just retired.

loans.use: to repair a damaged stable roof.

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en:
Jackson is a married man of 72 years living in Kyenjojo-Uganda. 

His business is buying and selling produce, mainly maize and beans. He ventured into this business in order to meet the family's needs. 

His business vision is to expand his business to greater heights despite the challenge of changes in the prices of produce. 

Jackson is requesting a loan to buy maize to sell.

loans.use: to buy maize to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more stock of charcoal

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a widowed woman with 6 children. She describes herself as a risk taker. She operates a farm of dairy cows and grows vegetables. She has been involved in this business for 30 years. Her business is located in a rural area and she has daily customers. 

Her biggest challenge is inadequate finances. She will use 50,000 KES to buy a dairy cow to enable her to increase milk production. Her business goal is to expand the business within 5 years. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance banak. Previous loan was repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to take care of her family.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: La Victoria Group

texts.es:
El comité La victoria está en su ciclo 16 del programa de comité de mujeres emprendedoras, donde todas mantienen una actividad propia emprendidas por ellas mismas, trabajan y se ayudan por salir adelante, son mujeres muy luchadoras, que luchan por sus familias.
Elisa es una de las integrantes de este grupo, ella se dedica a la venta de helados, y por medio de este oficio tiene los medios para poder ayudar a sus seres queridos. Comenta que le va muy bien ya que tiene muy buena clientela, y es gracias a esto que esta saliendo adelante. 
Ella esta poniendo su mejor esfuerzo para seguir creciendo y luchando, pide este préstamo para poder comprar una mayor variedad de helados, de manera a poder seguir con sus ventas. Todas agradecen por la oportunidad que están recibiendo de poder mejorar su estilo de vida.
texts.en:
The La Victoria community bank has opened its 16th round of funding to its members.  The members, all women, own small businesses that provide much-needed incomes for their families.
Elisa is one member of the group.  She operates an ice cream sales business and says that it is her means of helping her family move ahead.  She has many regular customers and works hard at growing the business and ensuring that it is successful.  She is applying for a loan that she will use to stock her business with different kinds of ice cream. 
The bank's members are grateful for your help and the opportunities your loans provide for improving their standards of living.

loans.use: to stock her ice cream sales business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more stock of tailoring materials

loans.name: Faith

texts.en:
Faith is a married woman. She has 2 children. She describes herself as kind and determined. 

She operates a tailoring shop where she makes clothes. She has been involved in this business for 3 years. Her business is located in a marketable place and her primary customers are the general public. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds. 

She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of tailoring materials. Her business goal is to own a large fashion design shop within 5 years. She hopes that, in the future, she will expand her business. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: buy more stock of tailoring materials

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is a married woman with 4 children ranging in age from 5  to 16 years. She describes herself as industrious. She has operated a retail business to sell cerea for 10 years. Her business is located in a rural area and her primary customers are local people. 

Her challenge is poor road conditions. She will use 20,000 KES to buy cereal. She hopes that in the future, she will own a cereal store. 

This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy cereal.

loans.name: Irine

texts.en:
Irine is a widowed woman. She has two children. She describes herself to be honest. She operates a retail shop where she sells clothes. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more stock of clothes.

Her business goal is to excel within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will be prosperous. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes.

loans.name: Milkah

texts.en: Milkah is married and the mother of three children. She describes herself as determined, and earns a living by running a retail business where she sells chicks. She has been in this line of work for three years and operates her business in a good area with many different types of customers. She says her biggest challenge is a lack of capital to buy more stock. Milkah is requesting a Kes 100,000 loan to buy more chicks to sell. She hopes that in the future, she will be prosperous. She is requesting her third loan, after successfully repaying her two prior ones. She will use the profits she expects to earn to educate her children.

loans.use: to buy more chicks

loans.name: Teona

texts.en: Teona is 25 years old. She lives in Kutaisi, Georgia with her husband and a pensioner mother-in-law. Teona is pregnant. Her husband is a builder and earns a monthly income. Teona wants to start business to help her family financially. The Startup Loan Program through Credo, which is a partner with Kiva, enables her to get a loan of $2300 to start a trading business. With the loan she will purchase a stock of clothes and linens to resell from her home. This will give her a chance to increase the family income and improve the living conditions for her family.

loans.use: to buy clothes and linens for resale.

loans.name: Gerald

texts.en:
Gerald is a married man. He has 5 children with ages ranging from 4 years to 13 years. He describes himself as determined. 

He operates a retail business where he sells spare motor vehicle parts. He has been involved in this business for 6 years. His business is located in a good area and his primary customers are vehicle owners. 

He will use the Kes 50,000 loan to buy more stock of spare vehicle parts. His business goal is to be a supplier within 5 years. He hopes that, in the future, he will own a big spare parts shop. 

This is his third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. His previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: buy more stock of spare vehicle parts

loans.name: Ibrashima

texts.en: Ibrashima is a maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Ibrashima would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Ibrashima can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Like other Babban Gona members, Ibrashima is looking  to earn a better income to provide more food and clothing for his family, and hopes to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: to purchase storage for his crops.

loans.name: Antigona

texts.en: In this photograph we see Antigona and her husband, Kurti, with their one-year-old daughter. They have another child who is five years old. Kurti earns a living by using the minibus we see in the photograph to transport people. Recently, the vehicle broke down and Kurti needs to repair it as this is the only source of income for his family. In their area, heavy snows have already started and he cannot operate the van in its current condition. In addition to this van, couple owns a dairy cow which they use to provide staple food and allow them to sell a bit of raw milk and one baby calf a year.

loans.use: to repair a minibus she and her husband use to transport people.

loans.name: Naheeda

texts.en:
Naheeda, 42 years old, is a married woman. Her husband is also shown in the photo. He has been successfully running a shopkeeping business for many years. He offers a variety of daily use products and has a good client base. 

In order to avoid shortages, he needs to have various goods in stock to efficiently meet customer demand. Naheeda has requested a loan of PKR 30,000 for her husband to buy additional grocery items including oil, milk, sugar and juices to consistently meet customers’ demands in order to make better earnings.

loans.use: to buy additional grocery items including oil, milk, sugar and juices to consistently meet customers’ demands in order to make better earnings.

loans.name: Hamisu

texts.en: Hamisu is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Hamisu joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Mamuna, Hadiza and Halima.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Hamisu would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater to his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Hamisu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Hamisu  spoke of his  ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to pay for school fees and uniforms thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Nuestra Señora De La Asuncion Group

texts.es:
El grupo Nuestra señora de la Asuncion está en su 6° ciclo  del programa de comité de mujeres emprendedoras, donde todas se ayudan y trabajan juntas por salir adelante. Se auto evaluaron con la encuesta de eliminación de pobreza para saber en que nivel están.
Una de las integrantes es la Sra. Cesaria, donde ella a través del esfuerzo y el trabajo continuo mas las ganas de salir adelante y la aplicaciones de los comportamientos vitales de una mujer exitosa, ella se encuentra mejorando su situación de pobreza. Ella se dedica a la costura, y pide este préstamo para la compra de telas, hilos, gomas, cierres y demás, de manera a poder seguir con su trabajo como lo viene haciendo.
texts.en:
The Nuestra Señora de la Asuncion community bank has opened its 6th round of funding to its members.  The members, all women, own small businesses that provide much-needed incomes for their families.  Members are polled to assess their level of need.
Sra. Cesaria is one member of the group.  She has worked hard, driving ahead to overcome every obstacle, in order to lift herself out of poverty.  She is a successful entrepreneur now with her own tailoring business.  She is applying for a loan that she will use to buy the supplies she needs--fabric, thread, zippers, etc.--to carry on her business.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian is a married woman. She has one child. She describes herself to be honest.

She operates a retail shop where she sells clothes. She has been involved in this business for four years. Her business is located in an urban area. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more stock of clothes.

Her business goal is to excel within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will excel in business. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes.

loans.name: Victoriana

texts.en:
Victoriana is a married woman with 1 child. She describes herself as a risk taker who sells eggs. She has been involved in this business for 4 years. Her business is located in an area with potential and she has regular customers. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate finances. 

She will use 100,000 KES to buy eggs. Her business goal is to expand within 5 years. She hopes to have a bright future. This is her fourth loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. Previous loans were successfully repaid. She will use the anticipated profits to meet her family's needs.

loans.use: to buy eggs.

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en:
Mahmoud is a 33-year-old married man. He is a Palestinian refugee who works hard to develop his business and support his family.
He is a hard worker, well known with his good reputation in his region and special talents in his business with 12 years of experience as a car mechanic.
Mahmoud cares a lot about his family and works hard to provide them with a better living. His acquired a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua which will be invested in helping his brother, who is building his house to settle down in a good region.
Mahmoud is working hard to buy his own garage, but in the meantime, he prefers to make sure that his brother will have a house of his own soon.

loans.use: To support his brother building his house

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married woman with 3 children. She describes herself as a risk taker and operates a retail business to sell maize flour, soap, bread, salt, mandazi, and other items. She has been involved in this business for 8 years. Her business is located in an area with potential and her primary customers are local people. 

She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate finances and will use 100,000 KES to buy maize flour, salt, sugar, bread, soap and other items. Her business goal is to an established wholesaler within 5 years. She hopes that  she will have a bright future. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. Previous loans were  successfully repaid. She will use the anticipated profits to meet her family's needs.

loans.use: to buy maize flour, salt, sugar, bread, soap and other items.

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en:
Christopher is a 36-year-old married man with six children living in Kyenjojo-Uganda. He trades in cattle and sells milk sales for extra income to meet his family's needs.

 Christopher intends to use the loan to buy cattle to sell ahead of the festive season. He is a determined man who desires to build a permanent house for his family even though he is challenged by inadequate capital and the prolonged dry spell affecting pasture growth.

loans.use: to buy cattle to sell ahead of the festive season.

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela is a married woman. She has six children. She describes herself to be honest.

She operates a restaurant where she cooks food to sell. She has been involved in this business for ten years. Her business is located in a good area, and her primary customers are individuals.

She will use the KES 50,000 loan to buy more stock of ingredients for preparing food to sell.

Her business goal is to have more business outlets within five years. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of ingredients.

loans.name: James,

texts.en: James will use the loan to buy general merchandise, mainly water, to sell ahead of the festive season. He is a married man with three children, two of whom attend school. He owns a retail shop as his only business, which he started with the purpose of improving his standard of living and that of his family at large. His desire is to build a permanent house and trade in wholesale only and he is challenged by price fluctuations and customers who don’t pay on time.

loans.use: to buy general merchandise, mainly water, to sell ahead of the festive season.

loans.name: Aloys

texts.en:
Aloys is 41 years old. He is married with 4 children aged between 6 and 17 years old. All of them go to school. He is a farmer and has been farming for 8 years. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to buy more fertilizers for maize to sell. The profits from the business will be used to buy food for home consumption.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers for maize to sell.

loans.name: Gulzat

texts.ru: Гулзат, 39 лет, замужем, есть 3 детей. У Гулзат - среднее образование, в качестве основного дохода для своей семьи, она с 2000 года занимается животноводством. У Гулзат в хозяйстве есть 2 дойные коровы, 3 овцы и 3 лошади. Благодаря упорному труду Гулзат и ее дружной семьи, бизнес приносит ежемесячную прибыль в размере примерно 20,000 сом (KGS), в основном от реализации экологически чистого, вкусного домашнего молока. Поэтому, в целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Гулзат обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на покупку дойных коров для увеличения объемов реализации молока. Увеличение поголовья позволит развить ее бизнес и увеличить доходы семьи. Доходы от кредита Гулзат планирует вложить в дальнейшее расширение ее бизнеса.
texts.en: Gulzat is 39 years old, married and has 3 children. Gulzat has a secondary education and, to provide the primary income for her family, has been involved in animal husbandry since 2000. Gulzat's farm contains 2 dairy cows, 3 sheep and 3 horses. Thanks to Gulzat's and her friendly family's hard work, the business yields a monthly profit in the amount of about 20,000 som (KGS), primarily from selling ecologically-clean and delicious, home-made milk. This is why, in order to further develop her business, Gulzat requested a loan in the amount of 100,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum" Bank to buy dairy cows to increase milk sales. Increasing the livestock headcount will allow her to grow the business and increase the family's income. Gulzat is planning to invest the earnings from the loan into further expanding her business.

loans.use: to buy dairy cows in order to increase sales of ecologically-clean milk

loans.name: Asifa

texts.en:
Asifa is a married woman. Her husband is also shown in the photo. He has been successfully running a shopkeeping business for many years. He offers a variety of daily use products and has a good client base. 

In order to avoid shortages, he needs to have various goods in stock to efficiently meet customer demand. For this reason, Asifa has taken a murabaha loan of 30,000 PKR for her husband to buy additional grocery items including oil, milk, sugar and juices to consistently meet customers’ demands so as to make better earnings.

loans.use: to buy additional grocery items including oil, milk, sugar and juices to consistently meet customers’ demands so as to make better earnings.

loans.name: Yusuf

texts.en: Yusuf is a maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Yusuf would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Yusuf can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Like other Babban Gona members, Yusuf is looking  to earn a better income to provide more food and clothing for his family, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to purchase storage for his crops.

loans.name: Ishaku Idi

texts.en:
Ishaku Idi is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Ishaku Idi joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Nasara, Rahmatu and Rose.  

Before he became a Babban Gona member, Ishaku Idi would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater to his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Ishaku Idi can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

When asked, Ishaku Idi spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to pay for school fees and uniforms, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Alh. Abdulkareem

texts.en: Alh. Abdulkareem is a maize farmer who lives in Furana village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, he had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, he can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40 percent more than the market price at harvest. Alh. Abdulkareem, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest time.

loans.name: Hauwa Ishaku

texts.en:
Hauwa Ishaku is a maize farmer from the village of Bawa Wambai in the state of Kaduna. Before she became a Babban Gona member, Hauwa Ishaku would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest to cater for her immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Hauwa Ishaku can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

Hauwa Ishaku, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand her farmland, and hopes to ensure her children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy ingredients to make tandir bread, increase business, and improve quality

loans.name: Unidas Group

texts.es:
El comité Unidas está en su ciclo 3 del programa de comité de mujeres emprendedoras, todas están luchando y se esfuerzan por poder crecer y ser mejores cada vez mas en sus emprendimientos.  Son mujeres emprendedoras donde la mayoría tienen su actividades particulares.
Norma se dedica a la venta de cosméticos varios, es una mujer muy trabajadora y por sobre todo emprendedora, que lucha por poder crecer y mejorar su vida y la de su familia. Ella esta mejorando gracias a su esfuerzo y quiere seguir haciéndolo, es por ello que se esta esforzando bastante.
Pide este préstamo para la compra de cosméticos varios y de esa forma poder seguir con sus ventas como lo viene haciendo. Agradece por esta oportunidad que recibe que le será de mucha ayuda.
texts.en:
The Unidas community bank has opened its 3rd round of funding.  Its members, all women, own small businesses that provide much-needed incomes for their families.  All work hard to maintain and grow their businesses.  
Norma operates a cosmetics sales business.  She works hard but, above all, she is smart and enterprising.  The business is her means of growing as a person and helping her family get ahead so its success is doubly-important to her.  She is applying for a loan that she will use to stock her business with all kinds of beauty products.  The investment will help her to continue the business.
Norma is grateful for this opportunity and says that your loans are a big help to her.

loans.use: to stock her cosmetics sales business.

loans.name: Zaituna

texts.en:
Zaitun is 36 years old and lives in the town of Mbale in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has 5 children, with 3 of them currently in school. For the past 5 years, Zaitun has been working hard to manage her beauty salon, which does hair dressing. 

To help expand her business, Zaitun has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more hair relaxers and braids for the salon, and will help Zaitun to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children, and to cover other basic needs. Zaitun hopes that, in the future, she will be able to expand the business into a vocational school and also build rental houses. 

Zaitun is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Zaitun who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more hair relaxers and braids for the salon

loans.name: Lyrma

texts.en:
Lyrma is a 40-year-old resident of Coron, Palawan, Philippines who is married to Raffu  (her business partner). She has four children; two attend college, one  is in elementary school and the other not of school age. She anad her husband work hard to meet their daily household and educational needs.

Lyrma has been in the food business for a number of years and cooks and sells a variety of small portions of food. In the Philippines pica-pica means finger foods, usually snacks. It is a common sight especially in populated area. She is a good cook and her food stall is popular in their area with neighbors and the local working community.  She earns a minimum of 900 PHP income a day. Aside from her food stall she also sells fresh meat.

To help her maintain her business, Lyrma requests 20,000 PHP to buy pork, fish, chicken, and seasonings. She thanks God and you in advance for a good return on her investment and the financial help, for it will surely cover their daily living expense and her children's education.

Lyrma wants to build and expand her business to secure the education of her children for them to have a bright future.  She meets weekly with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business and draws strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients to make pica-pica (finger foods) for sale.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is a married woman with 4 children. She operates a farm to grow maize and other crops. She has been involved in this business for 6 years. Her business is located in a strategic location. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate finances. She will use 20,000 KES to buy fertilizer, seeds and other farm supplies to increase production.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, seeds and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Saidu

texts.en:
Saidu is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Saidu would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to cater for his immediate cash needs.

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Saidu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest.

When asked about his goals, Saidu expressed a desire to use the extra income to build a better home, and in the long run, become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell his corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert, who owns a workshop, is a hardworking married man with two children living in Kyenjojo, Uganda. He rents out his planing machine and also makes furniture to make ends meet. 

Robert will use the loan to buy a motor vehicle for the workshop. This will help to provide easy means of transport for his customers, hence more business which will give him extra income. 

His challenges include a small capital base and inconsistency in power supply. His dream is to expand the output volume of the workshop.

loans.use: to buy a motor vehicle for the workshop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase construction materials to renovate the inside of the house.

loans.name: Amos

texts.en: Amos is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. He joined primarily to create a better future for his two children, Lorence and Mary. Before becoming a Babban Gona member, he had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Amos can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40 percent more than the market price at harvest. Amos speaks of his ambition to use the additional income he earns to educate his children, and of his hopes to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: to pay for school fees and uniforms, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest time.

loans.name: Saidu

texts.en:
Saidu is a maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Saidu would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to cater to his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Saidu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

Like other Babban Gona members, Saidu is looking to earn a better income to provide more food and clothing for his family, and hopes to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Nazier

texts.en:
Nazir once again thanks all of his Kiva lenders for doing a good job. Nazir paid his loan on time, and with the profits he was able to pay the tuition of his children. 

Nazir wants to save more for his children, because they will go to the city to study and the cost are very high. That's why Nazir wants to continue rice cultivation.

loans.use: to purchase diesel and fertilizer for his rice cultivation.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy beef, pork, mutton and poultry

loans.name: Mujeres Valientes Group

texts.es:
El grupo llamado Mujeres Mujeres Valientes son  de la ciudad de  San Ignacio, demuestran unidad y solidaridad entre ellas, trabajan juntas en actividades, manifiestan además que están conformes y sienten el apoyo del programa de comité de mujeres para que puedan ellas aumentar sus ingresos y ser cada vez más independientes.
La Sra. Cynthia es la presidenta del grupo, ella es estudiante y está trabajando en la venta de joyas variadas que vende en forma ambulante. Ella quiere mejorar su vida, es por eso que se está esforzando, pues estudia y a la vez trabaja. 
Pide este préstamo para la compra de joyas y su respectiva venta, de tal forma a poder generar ingresos para solventar sus estudios y también ayudar a sus padres. Cynthia de esta manera, busca su bienestar económico y la de su familia, sin descuidar sus estudios.
texts.en:
The members of the Mujeres Valientes community bank live in the city of San Ignacio.  The members, all women, are united and firm in their support of one another.  They are pleased, they say, with the program's support for their efforts to increase their incomes and become more independent.
Sra. Cynthia is the president of the group.  She is a student and operates a jewelry sales business.  She works as a street vendor and sells different kinds of jewelry.  She works hard, going to school all the while, because she wants a better life.  
Cynthia is applying for a loan that she will use to stock her jewelry sales business.  The investment will allow her to earn the money she needs to both help her family and finish her schooling.

loans.use: to stock her jewelry sales business.

loans.name: Narcisse

texts.en:
Narcicisse is 32 years old. He is married with three children aged between 1 and 6 years, two of whom go to school. He is a farmer and has been farming for eight years. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to buy more fertilizers for maize for sale. The profits from the business will be used to buy food for home consumption.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers for maize for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase rolls of electrical cable, satellite connection cable, and satellite dishes for his electrical business

loans.name: Fortunee

texts.en:
Fortunee is 42 years old and married with six children, ages 3 to 16 years old and all in school. She has been farming for 12 years. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to buy more fertilizer for maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for her children.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer for maize

loans.name: Leonard

texts.en:
Leonard is 37 years old and married with five children, ages 1 to 9, who all go to school. He has been farming for 11 years. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to buy more fertilizer for maize. The profits from the business will be used to buy food for his family.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer for maize

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cattle to fatten and sell

loans.name: Mika

texts.en:
Mika is a maize farmer from Kargo village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Mika would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to cater for his immediate cash needs.

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Mika can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest.

Mika, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell his corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Dharmradj

texts.en:
Dharmradj thanks all Kiva lenders once again for their help.

Dharmradj repaid his loan on time and could save money with the profits. He now needs to save more towards the purchase of a new tractor. Therefore he is requesting another loan of SRD 10,000 to purchase fertilizers and pesticides to continue to expand his rice production business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and pesticides so he can expand his rice production business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cartons of milk, maggi, bags of sugar and rice, etc.

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en: This is 39-year-old Zainab. She is a widow and has three children aged 8, 11, and 15 years old. She has three additional dependents who help her in her business and domestic work. In 2002, Zainab went into the business of selling cotton fabrics, a trade she learned from her mother after dropping out of school. Her business helped her before and after she got married to her late husband. Today, she works seven days a week and 12 hours a day and makes about Le 4,022,000 a month. She has successfully taken out and repaid six prior loans, and is requesting a new one for Le 5,000,000. Zainab plans to use the money to buy bales of English, Ivorian and other fabrics. In the future, she wants to expand her business and improve her family's life by opening a larger shop. She thanks Kiva lenders for their support, which helped her send one of her children to university.

loans.use: to buy different types of clothing for her business.

loans.name: Biliya

texts.en:
Biliya is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Biliya joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Habila, Luka, and Emma. 

Before he became a member, Biliya would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest in order to cater to his immediate cash needs, such as food and clothing for his family. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Biliya can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

He will use his loan funds to pay for his children's school fees and uniforms, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.
 
When asked, Biliya spoke of his ambition to use his additional income to educate his children, helping to ensure that they will one day qualify for professional jobs.

loans.use: to pay for school fees and uniforms for his children, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Damas Trabajadoras Group

texts.es:
El grupo llamado Damas trabajadoras esta dentro del programa de comité de mujeres, y también está dentro del programa de eliminación de la pobreza, que a través de la encuesta de los 50 indicadores podrán conocer la situación de vida de cada una y poder mejorar.
Eusebia es una de las integrantes, es una mujer digna y por sobre todo luchadora, quien se dedica al humilde trabajo del reciclaje, que ella misma sale a recolectar y también suele comprarlo y luego vende al por mayor. Ella lucha por poder salir adelante y dar a su familia todo lo que ella no pudo tener.
Eusebia pide este préstamo para la compra de metales, cartones, plásticos y demás, de manera a poder revender y seguir con su trabajo como lo viene haciendo.
texts.en:
The group "Damas Trabajadoras" ["Working Ladies"] is a committee of women involved in a program that works on the elimination of poverty. Through a survey 50 indicators, they can learn about the life situation of each person and can help to improve.

Eusebia is one of the members. She is an admirable and deserving woman but above all is tough and determined.  She is dedicated to the humble work of recycling. She goes out to collect items or buy them wholesale and then later resells them. She struggles to get ahead and gives her family everything she could not have.

Eusebia is requesting this loan to buy metals, cardboard, plastic, and other items so she can continue with her work reselling as she has been doing.

loans.use: to buy metals, cardboard, plastics and other items for resale.

loans.name: Idrissa

texts.en:
Idrissa, age 36, runs a business selling electronic items such as flashlights, radios, and recorders. He is the second-eldest of five children born to poor farmers who could not afford to send more than one child to school, so Idrissa helped his parents on the farm while his older brother was fortunate enough to attend school. When he became an adult, Idrissa decided to leave the village to look for new opportunities in larger towns. He started as a peddler, improved his business over the years, and started his electronic sales business in 2010. Working seven days a week and 12 hours a day, Idrissa earns about Le 2,349,000 every month from his business.

He and his wife have two children, ages five and seven years old. Both children attend school. He also supports two additional relatives, who help him in the business. 

Idrissa would like to request a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000. He has already received and successfully repaid two loans, and his business has improved greatly as a result. 

His new loan funds will allow him to buy assorted electronic goods for his shop. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy electronic flashlights and radios to offer for sale

loans.name: Isatu A.

texts.en:
This is 54-year-old Isatu A.  She is widowed, and has four children aged 34, 32, 30 and 27 years. In 1983, Isatu A. established her local food stuffs (rice, beans, wheat, etc.) business.  She began her business because she was brought up by her aunt, who did not send her to school, and her aunt was a petty trader whose business was the only source of income. She joined in the petty trading until she was mature enough to stand on her own.

Working 7 days a week and 11 hours a day, she earns about Le 4,375,000 every month from this business. 

She would like a loan in the amount of Le 5,000,000. Isatu A. has already received and successfully repaid three loans, and now requires a new loan in order to buy assorted bags of rice, beans, and sugar. 

In the future, Isatu A. is determined to strengthen her business to increase her capital.  The previous loan had helped her succeed in improving her business as planned, and also improved on the livelihood of her family.  

Competition and the rainy season are her main challenges.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase assorted bags of rice grains and sugar for resale.

loans.name: Mary H.

texts.en:
This is 38-year-old Mary H.  She is married, and has one child aged 20 years; The child goes to school (college level). She has one additional dependent who assist in domestic work and is fostered.  

In 2000, Mary H. established her beauty saloon (gels and hair attachments) business. She began her business because she was given away in an early marriage, as her supposed husband was a wealthy businessman. Her parents saw it as a means of survival for her to get married to him. When she got married, her aunt advised her to learn the hairdressing trade, which she did, and now she owns a shop.

Working 7 days a week and 12 hours a day, she earns about Le 2,705,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 4,500,000. 

Mary H. has already received and successfully repaid three loans, and now requires a new loan in order to purchase hair attachments, hair products and other cosmetics like body cream, shampoo, soap, hair cream, hair oil etc. 

In the future, Mary H. plans to put more effort in her business in order to save money for her daughter's education.  Her business has grown as planned and she has completed the payment of her land.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase hair attachments - Charming Hair , Expression Braiding Hair, Afro Kinking, and hair glue

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase different types of electronics items.

loans.name: Drane

texts.en:
