An amount of 100,000 Albanian Lek that she is requesting from Kiva lenders will help Drane pay the debts on the fodder she has bought on credit. 

“My animals needed to eat and I had no food for them; I begged some villagers around here so that I could buy from them and pay them later on when I had the money, and this is why I am seeking lenders' help,” said Drane.    

Drane is a married mother of four who has been doing agriculture/livestock for very many years now and this has been the only source of income for her entire family. She plants and sells large quantities of red/white cabbage, leeks, and spinach, as well as summer veggies and also plum/fig/pomegranate orchards and grapevines. As far as livestock, she’s got one dairy cow and two sows, poultry, and ducks.

loans.use: to pay off the debts from purchasing animal fodder from other villagers some time ago

loans.name: Fran

texts.en:
This is Fran and Luljeta, a married couple. They need your financial help to buy a stove that uses wood for warming, and also to pay for some electricity contract; they got the electricity from Fran’s father’s house that is next to his home. 

The couple has been married for long time, but "unfortunately" (quoted from them) they haven’t had any children yet. Fran works occasionally as a painter, while Luljeta works as a cleaner in a nearby restaurant, and also looks after an older couple.

loans.use: to buy a winter stove for warming up, and also to pay for some electricity contract for his home.

loans.name: Zakariya

texts.en:
Zakariya is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Zakariya joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Michel and Markus.

Before he became a Babban Gona member, Zakariya would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Zakariya can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest.

When asked, Zakariya spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children and his hope to eventually become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to pay for school fees and uniforms, thereby eliminating pressure to sell his corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Yakubu

texts.en:
Yakubu is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Yakubu joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Micah, Tabitha and Nathan.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Yakubu would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Yakubu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

When asked, Yakubu  spoke of his  ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to pay for school fees and uniforms thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Hajara

texts.en:
Hajara is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. She joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her children: Alheri, Asabe and Dauda.  Before she became a Babban Gona member, Hajara would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for her immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Hajara can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Hajara spoke of her ambition to use the additional income to educate her children, eventually hoping to make more money for herself and her family.

loans.use: to pay for school fees and uniforms, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Victor

texts.es:
Víctor tiene 43 años de edad, tiene hogar estable al lado de su cónyuge y una hija de 10 años de edad, estudia en escuela primaria del caserío el pueblo lo hizo; vive en casa propia de material rustico de un piso, él es nacido en caserío el pueblo lo hizo distrito santo tomas; vive en comunión con los miembros de su caserío, vive en una comunidad pequeña dedicada básicamente a la agricultura y a la ganadería; vive en la parte urbana del caserío el pueblo lo hizo Distrito de santo tomas; provincia de Cutervo, región de Cajamarca, sierra norte de Perú; vivienda cuenta con servicios de agua.

La actividad que realiza Víctor es el cultivo de café, contando a la fecha con 2 has. De terreno agrícola, de las cuales las 2 has tiene plantación Variedad catimor de dos y tres años de edad en primer y segundo año de producción, para campaña 2015 estará en segundo y tercer año de producción, actividad la realiza hace tres años en caserío el pueblo lo hizo Distrito santo tomas, cuenta con experiencia en el rubro del cultivo de café; producto lo vende en distrito santo tomas a compradores de la zona. Adicionalmente Víctor se dedica a la cría y venta de ganado vacuno contando con 4 reses de su propiedad y al cultivo de productos de pan llevar todo esto lo realiza en terreno propio en otro parte del caserío el pueblo lo hizo distrito santo tomas. El destino del crédito sera para mantenimiento de 2 has. De café en producción, con ello asegurara mayor y mejor producción para campaña 2015 y por ende obtendrá mayores ingresos para así poder mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Victor, 43, and his wife have a 10-year old daughter who is studying at the local primary school.  Their simple, one-story house is in a small rural town in the district of San Tomas.  The house is basic but has running water.  San Tomas is in a mountain region of Peru called Cajamarca.  Most of the people here make their livings farming or raising livestock.

Victor has a coffee planting business.  He has 2 hectares of land now where he is growing a variety of coffee called Catimor.  The plants are between one- and two-years old now.  Victor has grown coffee here for 3 years and knows the business well.  He sells his crop to local buyers in San Tomas.  He also raises cattle and grows grain crops on other land in the area.  Victor is applying for a loan that he will use to maintain his coffee crop.  The investment will ensure that he can maximize his 2015 yield and, in turn, generate a larger income for himself and his family.

loans.use: to buy supplies for his coffee planting business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase a wide variety of thread and other supplies to fill the orders that she has received.

loans.name: Marfita

texts.en:
This is Marfita, a 46-year-old, married lady who does embroidery, as seen in the photograph, for her living.  She will use 85% of the loan amount of 250,000 ALL that she is requesting from Kiva lenders, in her activity, and the rest on her family house. 

 Marfita has a large clientele who buys her crafts here in Korce, the city of her residence, and gift stores in the national capital city, but she also sells them to Italy and Greece upon requests. According to her, during the winter times she is much busier than summer or other seasons.

loans.use: to use 85% of the loan in her embroidery activity, and to use the rest on her family house.

loans.name: Lula

texts.en:
Lula wants to buy 20 sheep and with the rest of the loan, transport the sheep.

Lula is 41 and a married mother of three children; 14, 10 and 9 years old. Agriculture/livestock is what she has been pursuing for long time; currently, she’s got three dairy cows and sells almost three baby calves/year in addition to the raw milk. She also has 18 sheep from which she sells raw milk and baby ones. 

Now she wants to add more to the herd, and make it a little mini-farm; this is why she needs your help this time. As far as agriculture, she plants and sells corn, and has 56 olive trees and sells raw olives to those who want to make pickles.

loans.use: to add some 20 sheep to the existing herd

loans.name: Maryamu

texts.en:
Maryamu is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Maryamu joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her children: Safiratu, Christiyana, and Yuwana.

Before she became a Babban Gona member, Maryamu would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest to cater for her immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Maryamu can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest.

When asked, Maryamu spoke of her ambition to use the additional income to educate her children, and her hope to eventually become the most profitable farmer in her community.

loans.use: to pay for school fees and uniforms, thereby eliminating pressure to sell her corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Gloria joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her children: Sadiq, Ibrahim and Bilkisu.  Before she became a Babban Gona member, Gloria would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest to cater for her immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Gloria can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

When asked, Gloria  spoke of her ambition to use the additional income to educate her children, eventually hoping to ensure her children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to pay for school fees and uniforms thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Parachichi Group

texts.en:
Christina is a food vendor, running a "mamalishe" (food kiosk) business. She has been engaged in this business for 10 years now. She works from 5:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. daily and is able to make a good monthly profit. She is in her late forties and has two children who attend school. 

This will be Christina's fourth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used her previous loans to to buy tables and replenish the out-of-stock items in her mamalishe business. She has repaid all her loans successfully. She is doing great as a result of her previous loans. She has used her increased profit to pay school fees, increase her savings in the bank, and cover household expenses.  

She will use her current loan funds to buy plastic chairs and tables and to replenish her stock for her mamalishe business.  

She dreams eventually of building a house for her family.

Christina will share this loan with her loan group, "Parachichi," which consists of five members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy plastic chairs and tables and to replenish her stock for her food vending business

loans.name: Kuña Guapa Group

texts.es:
El grupo lleva por nombre Comité de Kuña Guapa son  de la ciudad de San  Ignacio, ellas son unidas y solidarias entre ellas, trabajan juntas en actividades, manifiestan que están conformes y sienten el apoyo del programa de comité de mujeres para que puedan ellas aumentar sus ingresos y ser cada vez más independientes.
La Sra. Crisolina es la presidenta del grupo, ella está casada y tiene 2 hijas, todos en la casa colaboran con el desarrollo y el crecimiento del nivel de vida de la familia. 
La Sra. Crisolina  solicita  este préstamo para invertir en su negocio que es la producción de productos de limpieza y  la venta correspondiente. Ya que tiene mucho éxito con sus ventas, ella desea progresar cada día más y gracia al programa está logrando sus objetivos.
texts.en: The group called 'Comité de Kuña Guapa' is from the city of San Ignacio. They are united and supportive of one another. They work together on activities. They say they are satisfied and can feel the support of the women's committee program so they can increase their income and be increasingly independent. Mrs. Crisolina is the president of the group. She is married and has 2 daughters. Everyone in the house collaborates with the development and the growth of living standards in the family. Mrs. Crisolina requests this loan for investing in her business, which is the production of cleaning products and the corresponding sale. She has already had much success with these sales. She wishes to progress more every day and is thankful the program is reaching its objectives.

loans.use: Buy supplies for the production of cleaning products

loans.name: Les Disciples (2) Group

texts.en:
Ferdinand is 61 years old and the single father of nine children, ages 33 to nine months, three of whom are still in school. In order to support his large family, Ferdinand ran a photo business for years, taking pictures for peoples’ identity cards in Brazzaville. 

As he has gotten older however, Ferdinand has had trouble keeping up with his photo business, since it requires him to be quite active. As such, a few years ago he opened a small grocery store on his own land and began selling various food items. In order to help grow his fledgling business, Ferdinand joined HOPE Congo in 2012. 

Ferdinand is a member of the community bank group LES DISCIPLES (2), and helps lead a subgroup of eight other micro-entrepreneurs who live and work in Brazzaville, the Republic of Congo. Now on his fifth loan cycle with HOPE Congo, Ferdinand would like to take out a loan of 350,000 CFA to purchase additional drinks, oil, rice and bread to sell at his shop. 

In the future, Ferdinand dreams of transforming his land into a hotel to welcome various guests and travelers, and he already has the name picked out, “Flamingo Hotel”. He hopes that all of his children will be able to finish their education and find job opportunities after school.

loans.use: to purchase additional drinks, oil, rice and bread to sell at his shop.

loans.name: Les Disciples (1) Group

texts.en:
Yannick is a young entrepreneur who works and lives in Brazzaville, the Republic of Congo. Five years ago Yannick opened a small stand selling SIM cards for mobile phones in the market of Brazzaville. A year later he was able to branch out into selling the phones themselves in addition to just the SIM cards. 

In 2012, Yannick was able to join the community bank group LES DISCIPLES (2) at HOPE Congo. The leader of a subgroup of nine other micro-entrepreneurs in Brazzaville, Yannick is now on his sixth loan cycle with HOPE Congo and would like to take out a loan of 400,000 CFA next. 

With this additional credit, Yannick will be able to open his third phone cabinet and fully stock it with phones, SIM cards and phone credit for people to buy.

Eventually, Yannick hopes to open five to six phone cabinets throughout the city of Brazzaville. One day he even dreams of being able to travel abroad to China or Dubai and start a business buying mobile phones in bulk and selling them back in Brazzaville.

loans.use: to open a new phone stand and stock it with phones, SIM cards and phone credit.

loans.name: Leatu

texts.en:
Leatu is a maize farmer from Kwankwani village in Kaduna state. Before she became a Babban Gona member, Leatu would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest to cater for her immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Leatu can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

Leatu, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand her farmland, and hopes to ensure her children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Tout Va Bien (2) Group

texts.en:
Only 27 years old, Christ is responsible for taking care of his two young nephews. In order to help provide for them, for the last six years Christ has run his own business selling gasoline in bottles at his roadside stand. The market is difficult however, and prices fluctuate often. Looking ahead to the future, Christ believes that selling gasoline will become extremely difficult and wants to change his business and go into dry-cleaning clothes and cleaning houses. 

Last year, Christ joined the community bank group TOUT VA BIEN (2) and helps lead a small subgroup of 12 other micro-entrepreneurs who live and work in Brazzaville, the Republic of Congo. 

Now on his second loan cycle with HOPE Congo, Christ hopes to take out a loan of 300,000 CFA to invest in his gasoline business and begin to diversify his products to get closer to his goal. With this money, Christ will purchase additional bottles of gasoline, as well as tinder and small portable stoves. He hopes to bring in enough profit to move forward with his cleaning businesses and start purchasing dry-cleaning equipment. 

One day, Christ hopes to be able to travel abroad and see other countries, such as South Africa, for himself.

loans.use: to buy additional bottles of gasoline as well as tinder and small portable stoves

loans.name: Tout Va Bien (1) Group

texts.en:
For the last nine years, Gracia has run various businesses. Most recently she has began traveling to Cotonou in Benin, to purchase bowls, which she then resells in Brazzaville. Times have been difficult however, and it has been hard to have the money to pay all of the customs fees. As a mother of four, who also takes care of her two granddaughters and a nephew, Gracia has a large family to think about. In the last year, her business has begun to grow, helped in part by joining the community bank group TOUT VA BIEN (1) with HOPE Congo. Within TOUT VA BIEN (1), Gracia became the leader of a sub-group of 12 other micro entrepreneurs, who live and work in Brazzaville, the Republic of Congo. 

Gracia is now on her third loan cycle with HOPE Congo and plans to take out her next loan of 450,000 CFA, in order to travel once more to Cotonou to purchase a stock of higher quality bowls. She is also able to pay the cost of the customs fees with the help of her community bank group credit and looks to grow her business in the future to buying and selling other household items. 

One day, Gracia would even like to expand to having her own drinks depot. Despite her grand plans for her business, Gracia’s true dream for the future is that her children would be able to succeed. She hopes to be able to have enough profits to continuing paying for their education, and prays that they will all be able to finish their studies out well.

loans.use: to purchase a higher quality stock of bowls to sell.

loans.name: Rashila

texts.en:
Rashila is a maize farmer from Kwankwani village in Kaduna state. Before she became a Babban Gona member, she would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for her immediate cash needs. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Rashila can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Rashila, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand her farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in her community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Mont Carmel (1) Group

texts.en:
Looy is a young entrepreneur from Brazzaville, the Republic of Congo, who is full of creativity. A few years ago she had her own hair salon for women, but things were not going well. Not many clients came to her neighborhood for hairstyling and so she decided to start her own small grocery store out of her home last year. 

The mother of two young children, ages eight and 15 months, Looy has been looking for a way to expand her small shop from just dried and canned goods to having a small butcher shop as well. In order to bring about her plan, when Looy heard about HOPE Congo, she joined the community bank group MONT CARMEL (1).  

Leading up a subgroup of eleven other micro-entrepreneurs from Brazzaville, Looy plans to take out a loan of 250,000 CFA. With this small loan, Looy will be able to launch herself into her second activity: having a butcher shop. She will be able to purchase meats such as chicken, pork and beef to sell. 

Looy’s strategy to draw in clients is simple: smile and make them laugh! She likes to encourage her faithful clients by throwing in a gift every now and then to keep them coming back. In the future, Looy hopes to expand her business to the point of owning multiple stores that include butcher shops. She dreams of her children being able to keep moving forward, to be able to finish their studies and eventually travel outside of Congo-Brazzaville.

loans.use: to purchase meat such as chicken, pork and beef for her shop.

loans.name: Angel

texts.en:
Angel raises cows and sheep, which he later sells to other farmers or slaughterhouses in the region. Although he does not sell their milk, he milks the cows from time to time for his family's consumption. He also owns some land close to his house, where he produces forage to feed his animals. He is looking forward to reducing his operating expenses by displacing the expensive and non-renewable LP gas, and to produce his own organic fertilizer with the Sistema Biobolsa biodigester. 

By using his animals' manure as a resource, he only needs to put it in the biodigester, he will be able to use biogas to cook and heat water in the house. The bacteria in the biodigester also transform the waste into a potent, nutrient-rich biofertilizer, which Angel will spread on his field to increase the yield of the forage and to restore the soils in a natural way. His animals' waste will not be piled up outside his farm anymore, where it used to attract swarms of flies and contaminate underground water sources. 

Angel's farm will become a cleaner and more comfortable place to live. He plans to invest part of his additional available income in the expansion of the stable for his cows and sheep. This loan represents 20% of the total cost of the biodigester. The remaining part is being covered by a government subsidy.

loans.use: to purchase a 14 m3 Sistema Biobolsa biodigester.

loans.name: Mont Carmel (2) Group

texts.en:
At 25 years old, Memeci has a head for business. For the last few years he has been working in construction in Brazzaville, but he has big plans. Wanting to evolve more than the odd construction job would allow him, Memeci recently took the initiative to open his own perfume and toiletries shop. 

A member of the community bank group MONT CARMEL (2), Memeci helps lead a subgroup of eleven other micro-entrepreneurs from Brazzaville, the Republic of Congo. Through MONT CARMEL (2), Memeci wants to take out his very first business loan of 250,000 CFA to invest in his shop. 

With this money, Memeci will be able to fully fill out his new store with merchandise, allowing him to purchase perfumes, cologne, deodorants, creams and hair products. In the future, Memeci dreams of making enough of a profit to launch himself into the traveling commerce business as well. He hopes to travel to Dubai one day and create a business in Brazzaville selling imported cars. 

For himself, Memeci plans to slowly save enough money to be able to purchase his own piece of land and build his own house.

loans.use: to purchase beauty products and toiletries for his shop.

loans.name: Molende (1) Group

texts.en:
Alban is a young husband and father of three. In addition to looking after his family, he also takes care of his younger sister and brother at home. In order to support this extended family, Alban started a small grocery store out of his home three years ago. 

This year Alban learned about HOPE Congo and joined the community bank group MOLENDE (1). The leader of a subgroup of eleven other micro-entrepreneurs from Brazzaville, the Republic of Congo, Alban hopes to take out his first loan of 250,000 CFA. 

With this money, Alban will be able to purchase additional goods for his store, such as cartons of milk, bars of soap and matches. In addition, he wants to start up a music business in his shop and will purchase CDs to sell.

Alban wants to help others in his community, especially by helping teach one of his trades, including his former business of making and selling photocopies, or running their own grocery stores. He also dreams of being able to pass along his business knowledge to his oldest daughter and younger brother.

loans.use: to purchase additional goods for his store.

loans.name: Las Margaritas Group

texts.en:
The Trust Bank “Las Margaritas” is located in Santa Clara La Laguna and is composed of nine ladies who have successfully completed their loan cycle, funded by Kiva investors. The loans were funded last May and were quite useful for the women. The ladies generated income and were able to cover the basic necessities of their families. They are requesting a new loan that they hope will be funded by Kiva investors.

Lidia is a member of the Trust Bank with six years of formal education. She is 29 years old, and a single mother of one small daughter. Lidia is very motivated to meet every need of the little girl and strives to work hard each day. Most importantly, she wants her daughter to have a good education. Lidia raises poultry and recently added another business selling sandals. She is requesting a loan that she will use to buy more poultry and sandals. Lidia is quite pleased with the results of her efforts.

The educational component of the monthly Trust Bank meetings gives the women concrete information that helps them realize their dreams. They learn to get their children ready for school, feed them nutritious meals, support their health and teach them about good hygienic practices. The ladies become more informed business entrepreneurs with information about budgeting, pricing, marketing, and customer service and accounting.

Kiva investors are valuable partners with Friendship Bridge in helping these women help themselves. The ladies of “Las Margaritas” are grateful to step into a brighter future, benefitting themselves, their families and their community in Santa Clara La Laguna. Thank you, Kiva investors.

loans.use: to buy more poultry and sandals for her businesses.

loans.name: Atitecas Group

texts.en:
Santiago Atitlán is a large and busy Tzutujil Maya speaking town located on the south shore of Lake Atitlán. It is quite picturesque with volcanoes on either side. This past March, seven indigenous women, determined to empower themselves and eliminate poverty, formed the Friendship Bridge Trust Bank “Atitecas.” They understood that the organization's “Microcredit Plus” Program, which combines small loans and education, would benefit them greatly. The ladies report that they have paid back their first loan in full. They were pleased to generate additional income, some of which was used for educational expenses for their children.  Dora, who we previously reported on, was happy to share that she was able to maintain and expand her shoe store.

Mercedes, the current Secretary of the Trust Bank, is 33 years of age and has two years of formal education. She has a traditional textile business weaving and embroidering by hand. She is requesting a loan that she plans to use to purchase thread and other supplies. At this time of the year, there are many tourists in the town, and Mercedes wants to have plenty of inventory available. Her dream is to increase sales and raise the standard of living for her family. 

The ladies of the Trust Bank attend monthly meetings with a Friendship Bridge Loan Officer. Besides making payments on their loans, the women gain personal and business tools that they can immediately use. They learn to take care of their families in a more healthy way with information about nutrition, health, hygiene, and the use of medicinal plants. They learn to have more self esteem with games and role playing. The ladies learn about children's and women’s rights. Finally, they gather useful information about effective business practices in order to successfully manage their loans.

Thank you, Kiva investors, for your kindness in funding loans for these women. We look forward to providing a follow up report on the “Atitecas” in the very near future.

loans.use: To purchase thread and other supplies

loans.name: Flor De Tzununa Group

texts.en:
The small community of Tzununa is located on the shores of Lake Atitlan in the Western Highlands of Guatemala. The Friendship Bridge Trust Bank “Flor de Tzununa,” meaning “Flower of Tzununa,” is located here and composed of seven women who share the common hopes of generating income in their small businesses, raising their living standards, taking care of their families and seeing their children go to school. 

Maria, a 20-year-old member of the Trust Bank, is Maya-Kaqchikel and has a traditional textile business. She is requesting a new loan that she will use to purchase a supply of various colors of thread, and other supplies, to create beautiful handmade cortes (woven skirts), huipiles (colorful blouses) and fajas (ornate belts). Maria lives with her parents and four siblings, and will use the earnings of her business to help support the family. As she was unable to complete elementary school, she works hard so that her siblings will be able to get a good education.

Maria is able to gain practical and important information each month at the meeting of the Trust Bank. Using games, drawings and role-playing, a Friendship Bridge Loan Officer shares pertinent information with Maria and her friends in the Trust Bank.  They learn about the world around them and within them, with educational seminars about nutrition, health, hygiene and the use of medicinal plants. The women empower themselves with information about their rights as women, self-esteem, and women’s health. They learn to effectively manage their loans with new business tools (accounting, budgeting, marketing, pricing, customer service).

Thanks to Kiva investors and Friendship Bridge, the six women of the “Flor de Tzununa” Trust Bank are stepping into a brighter and more successful future. We look forward to reporting on Maria and her friends in the Trust Bank in an upcoming report.

loans.use: to purchase a supply of various colors of thread and other supplies to create beautiful handmade cortes (woven skirts), huipiles (colorful blouses) and fajas (ornate belts).

loans.name: Lindita

texts.en:
Lindita is a member of the most vulnerable ethnic community of Albania. She lives in the city of Korca, is 43 years old and a divorced mother of a 21-year-old child. For some time now she has been feeling sick, and despite the fact that she has gone to a few doctors in her city who did not find anything to worry about, she is still convinced that there is something going on with her health. For this she has decided to go to some specialist in the capital city.  

Lindita sells new items as seen in the picture such as clothing, winter blankets and draperies.

loans.use: to pay for a medical visit to a specialist.

loans.name: Virgen De Fatima Group

texts.es:
Virgen de Fatima es un grupo relativamente nuevo, se ha hecho la encuesta de eliminación de pobreza con las integrantes donde algunas señoras se encontraban dentro de la línea de la pobreza, pero ya se ha trabajado con ellas para que vayan aumentando sus ingresos.
Una de las integrantes es la Sra. Liliana, Directora General del Comité, quien se dedica al comercio, es decir a la venta de Joyas de Plata a cuotas. Es una mujer muy trabajadora, que lucha por poder  crecer y salir adelante. Su esposo también trabaja, se dedica a realizar trabajos de tornería, y por medio del esfuerzo de ambos están mejorando sus condiciones de vida.
La Sra. Liliana solicita este préstamo para la compra de más variedad de joyas, es decir para capital de trabajo, ya que tiene mucha clientela.
texts.en: 'Virgen de Fatima' is a relatively new group. It did the elimination of poverty survey with their members, in which some women discovered they were under the poverty line, but it already has worked with them to start increasing their incomes. One of the members is Mrs. Liliana, Director General of the Committee, who makes a living in trade, i.e. the sale of silver jewellery on credit. She is a very hard-working woman, fighting to expand and succeed. Her husband also works. He makes a living making works of turning. Through both their efforts they are improving their living conditions. Mrs. Liliana is requesting this loan to buy a bigger variety of jewellery, i.e. working capital, because she already has many customers.

loans.use: buy jewellery to sell

loans.name: Molende (2) Group

texts.en:
Retie is a young single mother who owns a used clothing stand in Brazzaville, the Republic of Congo. In order to help grow her business, Retie joined HOPE Congo this year and became a member of the community bank group MOLENDE (2). 

Helping lead a subgroup of eleven other micro-entrepreneurs, Retie would like to take out a loan of 300,000 CFA. With this money she will be able to strengthen and expand her stock of clothing, purchasing two additional bundles of used clothing to sell. 

Retie prides herself on drawing in clients through the quality rather than the quantity of her clothing. In addition to her four-year-old-daughter, Retie also helps support her sister’s multiple children. 

While she only has a small table at the market now, Retie hopes to grow her business to having her own shop. She dreams of traveling abroad and purchasing quality clothing to sell in such a store. For her daughter, Retie hopes that she will go through school well and then be able to succeed doing something she is interested in.

loans.use: to purchase additional bundles of used clothing to resell.

loans.name: Burbuqe

texts.en: Burbuqe's son has been studying in a public university in the computer science field and she is requesting this loan to pay the tuition fees.

loans.use: to pay her son's university tuition fees.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy young fish and diversify agricultural production.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to build a latrine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase used handbags, schoolbags, and traveling bags for his retail business.

loans.name: Abelita

texts.en:
Abelita lives in Ermera, and she is married and has six children. She is a businesswoman, so she is applying for a loan of USD 600.00 from Tuba Rai Metin to improve her business. She is taking this loan because she wants to buy more clothes such as school trousers, sarongs, children's clothes, fabric doors, batik shirts, mother shirts, and other things to sell. 

Abelita started her business in 2004 with her own working capital of USD 400.00. She does not sell every day. She was just selling at market days, because wherever there is market day she would go sell there. She is earning a good income from her business, because many people are interested with her clothes. So she is very happy to do her business. With the loan from Tuba Rai Metin, she hopes to get a good management for her business.

loans.use: to buy school trousers, sarongs, children's clothes, fabric doors, batik shirts, mother shirts, and other things to sell.

loans.name: Bernardino

texts.en:
Bernardino owns several cows and lives on a farm with his family, where he dedicates himself to selling milk and cultivating corn as well as forage to feed the cows. When he found out about Sistema Biobolsa, he was very enthusiastic about the opportunity to close the natural cycle on his farm by producing his own biogas and organic fertilizer from his cows' manure. 

Indeed, by inputting their waste into the biodigester on a daily basis, he will not rely on external energy sources such as LP gas or wood to cook and heat water, nor on chemical fertilizers. His operating expenses will go down, while his crops' yield will increase as he spreads the nutrient-rich fertilizer on his fields. Also, his wife will not inhale toxic smoke anymore while she cooks. 

Further, the greenhouse gases generated by the waste will not contaminate the atmosphere anymore, as they will be transformed into methane-rich biogas inside the biodigester. With the savings he will make, Bernardino aims at expanding his farm and house.

Bernardino is pictured here on the day his biodigester was installed. This loan represents 20% of the total cost of the biodigester, the remaining part being covered by a government subsidy.

loans.use: to invest in a 10 m3 waste-to-energy biodigester.

loans.name: Rothanak

texts.en: Rothanak is 19 years old and he is a single, accounting freshman at university in a city. He is from Kandal Province, Cambodia. Because he is short of financial support, he would like to apply for a loan to pay his tuition fees for four years. This loan will help him graduate successfully and provide him with a skill for his future job. Rothanak dreams to work in a company with a decent salary to improve his living, and then he will able to save money to build a proper house.

loans.use: to pay his tuition fees.

loans.name: Muvafe Group

texts.es:
El grupo Muvafe está en el  ciclo número 5 del programa de Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras, ellas están haciendo la encuesta de eliminación de la pobreza, para que por medio de su trabajo y esfuerzo vayan mejorando sus condiciones de vida.
Una persona que se destaca es la Sra. Delia, quien también es la presidenta, es una persona que se esfuerza, y siempre trata de poder incentivar a sus compañeras a poder seguir creciendo en sus emprendimientos. Ella vende ropas variadas de manera ambulante, y comenta que por medio de este trabajo tiene los medios  para poder ayudar a su familia.
Delia pide este préstamo para poder invertirlo en la compra de prendas varias para la venta, como ser remeras, camisas, jeans, pantalones y demás, para poder seguir con sus ventas, luchando por crecer.
texts.en:
The Muvafe group is in its fifth season of the "Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras" (Entreprising Women's Committee) program. They are doing a survey on the elimination of poverty, so that through their work and efforts they are improving the conditions of their lives.

One person that stands out is Delia, who is also the president. She is an inspiring person, and she always tries to motivate her colleagues to be able to continue growing their business ventures. She sells a variety of clothing as a street vendor, and she mentions that by doing this work she has the means to help her family.

Delia is requesting this loan to purchase various garments to sell, such as T-shirts, shirts, jeans, pants and more, to continue with her sales, working hard to expand.

loans.use: to buy T-shirts, shirts, jeans, pants and more to sell.

loans.name: Luisita

texts.en:
Luisita is 51 years old and has five children. She is married and has one child who is still in school. She is in the agricultural business of raising livestock in the Philippines. Luisita has requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed, and vitamins and other supplies for her livestock.

Luisita has been raising livestock for 24 years now, and has borrowed six times in the past from NWTF to sustain it. She would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy livestock feed and vitamins.

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en: Vanna is 20 years old, and a single accounting freshman at university in a province. She is from Prey Veng Province in Cambodia. She is lacking of finances to pay her tuition fees for three years, so she would like to request a loan. With the loan, she will be able to graduate successfully with a chance for her future job. In the future, Vanna wants to work in a bank or microfinance institution, and then save money to build a proper house.

loans.use: to pay her tuition fees.

loans.name: Alfonsa

texts.en:
Alfonsa is a mom of a 14-year-old child. She engages in making and selling of candles. She is 41 years old, married, and residing in Baclayon, Bohol. She has been engaged in making candle for seven years. 

Alfonsa is asking for a loan of 20,000 PHP to buy wax, candlewicks, and plastic tape. In this way, she could produce and sell more candles to her respective buyers. This will help to augment her income, as she could now be able to afford to buy healthy foods for the whole family.

In the future, Alfonsa dreams to improve and expand her business, to make it successful in order to support the schooling of her daughter.

loans.use: to buy wax, candlewicks and plastic tape.

loans.name: Kuña Rory Group

texts.es:
El comité Kuña Rory están en el 3er. ciclo con 18 integrantes, es un grupo formado con la unión de amigas y vecinas de la ciudad de Santaní. Las integrantes formaron un grupo bastante unido, con  la  plena convicción de trabajar todas juntas, apoyándose mutuamente.
Una de las integrantes la señora Gloria, es muy emprendedora se dedica a la Repostería, hace tortas de distintos sabores, es bastante amable y con su carisma logra tener muchos clientes por la zona de la ciudad.
Ella pide este préstamo para poder comprar insumos varios para poder hacer sus reposterías, como ser harina, azúcar, manteca, huevos y demás. Agradecen todas por la oportunidad que están recibiendo de poder crecer.
texts.en:
The Kuña Rory committee is in its third cycle, with 18 members. The group is made up of the club of friends and neighbors from the city Santaní. The members constitute a well-knit group, with a strong commitment to work together and mutually support one another. 

Gloria is one of the members of this group. She is very proactive and her business is baking cakes. She makes various flavors of cakes, and is a cheerful person whose carisma helps her to have many clients in her area of the city. 

She is requesting this loan to buy ingredients to bake her cakes, such as flour, sugar, butter, eggs, and the rest. She thanks everyone for the opportunity to grow that she is being offered.

loans.use: to buy ingredients such as flour, sugar, butter, eggs, and the rest.

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
This is Letecia. She previously accessed a 20,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of biscuits and dried fish. Her earnings were a big help for her personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 20,000 PHP loan for her to buy additional merchandise and other products needed in her business. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result for better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Letecia wants to become a successful entrepreneur someday. She hopes that her business will continue to operate and help provide her daily needs. Every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from studying the Word of God.

* All Center for Community Transformation (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for an additional stock of biscuits and dried fish needed for her business.

loans.name: Sapbay

texts.en:
Sapbay, 53, is living in Kanal Province, Cambodia. She has three children in total; two are single and one is married. To make a living and support her family, she manages and operates a farming business on a small rice farmland, which is located near her house. So far, she has been in this type of business for more than 30 years. On average, she is able to make an income of USD 2.00 a day.

Sapbay wants to improve the general living conditions of the entire family by having a latrine to use, because there is no latrine in her house now. Therefore, she is borrowing a loan from Kiva to build a latrine. By doing this, she can help her family members gain access to sanitation, promote their health, and help to lessen environmental deterioration. She is thankful for the loan granted through HKL with a much lower interest rate than other general loan products.

loans.use: to build a latrine.

loans.name: Rahat

texts.ru: Рахат, 55 лет, вдова, мать 4 детей. У Рахат- среднее образование, уже 24 года занимается полеводством и животноводством. Стартовав с 6,000 сом (KGS), благодаря упорному труду, на сегодняшний день у Рахат имеется 0,16 ГА собственного земельного надела, на котором она ежегодно выращивает картофель, малину, яблони для реализации. Также в хозяйстве есть 2 коровы и 4 овцы. Ежемесячный доход составляет от 8,000 сом  до 10,000 сом (KGS). Этих средств катастрофически не хватает на достойную жизнь Рахат и ее детей. В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Рахат обратилась в Банк "Бай-Тушум" за кредитом в сумме 40,000 сом (KGS) для покупки овец. Доходы от кредита Рахат хочет вложить в приумножение количества домашней скотины, и планирует накопить средства на покупку земли.
texts.en: Rahat is 55 years old, a widow, and the mother of four. Rahat has received secondary education. For 24 years she has been growing farm produce and raising livestock. She started with 6,000 KGS. Thanks to Rahat’s hard work at present she has a land plot of 0.16 ha [0.4 acres], where she annual grows potatoes, raspberries and apples for sale. She also has two cows and four sheep. Her monthly revenue ranges from 8,000 to 10,000 KGS. This income is drastically insufficient to maintain a dignified quality of life for Rahat and her children. In order to develop her farm further, Rahat has applied to the Bai Tushum microfinance institution for a loan in the amount of 40,000 KGS to buy sheep. Rahat plans to use the resulting revenue for an additional livestock increase. She also plans to save up to buy a land plot.

loans.use: to purchase some sheep in order to increase her income.

loans.name: Alima

texts.ru: Алима, 56 лет, не замужем, есть 2 детей. У Алимы- среднее образование. В качестве основного дохода для своей семьи она на дому шьет матрацы, одеяла и прочие изделия для дома, стартовав 10 лет назад с 3,000 сомов (KGS). Благодаря упорному труду Алимы на сегодняшний день ее бизнес приносит около 10,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, она обратилась в Банк "Бай-Тушум" за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS) на покупку материала. Доходы от кредита Алима планирует вкладывать в дальнейшее развитие ее бизнеса.
texts.en: Alima is 56 years old, not married and has 2 children. Alima has a secondary education. To provide the primary income for her family, she sews mattresses, blankets and various items for home, having started 10 years ago with 3,000 som (KGS). Thanks to Alima's hard work, today her business yields about 10,000 som (KGS).  In order to further develop her business, Alima requested a loan in the amount of 50,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum" Bank to buy materials. Alima is planning to invest the earnings from the loan into further developing her business.

loans.use: to purchase materials in order to develop her business

loans.name: Nat

texts.en:
A resident of Kampong Speu province in Cambodia, Nat is a 45-year-old mother of four children in her care; two of them are garment workers, while another attends school. She has been a rice farmer for nearly 30 years, an occupation also pursued by her 50-year-old husband. Together, they can make $12 a day. 

Nat is requesting a loan to buy lumber, cement, bricks and zinc sheets to build a kitchen and a bathroom. This loan will provide her and her family with better living conditions. 

In the future, Nat plans to buy more farmland, build a fence around her house and support her child to finish high school.

loans.use: to buy lumber, cement, bricks and zinc sheets to build a kitchen and a bathroom

loans.name: Virgen De Caacupe Group

texts.es:
Virgen de Caacupe se formo en la ciudad de Santaní, son 17 mujeres, todas ellas mujeres jefas de familia que luchan por sus seres queridos y sus familias.
Una de las integrantes, la señora Ramona, se dedica a la venta ambulante de asaditos, bebidas, etc., es una mujer muy luchadora y trabajadora, que se está esforzando por poder crecer y mejorar para poder ayudar a su familia. 
Ramona pide el préstamo para la compra de insumos varios para sus ventas, como bebidas, carne, condimentos y demás, de manera a poder seguir con su trabajo como lo viene haciendo. Las integrantes formaron un grupo bastante unido, para poder trabajar de manera conjunta.
texts.en:
Virgen de Caacupe was formed in the city of Santaní by a group of 17 women. All of the women are heads of household that fight for their loved ones and their families. One of the members, Ramona, is a hard-working and persistent woman who makes her living as a street vendor, selling grilled meats, drinks, etc. She is working hard to grow and improve in order to help her family

Ramona requests this loan to purchase various supplies, such as drinks, meat, condiments, and more, so that she can continue working as she has been doing. The members set up a rather close-knit group so that they can work in a collaborative manner.

loans.use: to purchase drinks, meat, condiments, and more.

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios earns a living by providing homemade meals to customers in her community. She cooks her famous recipe called inun-unan, a popular Philippines recipe in which fish is cooked in garlic and vinegar. She is a 51-year-old married woman with four dependents. Her oldest child is 24 and the youngest is 16. Her husband earns a living by selling fish.

Remedios has requested a loan of 30,000 PHP to buy more supplies like fish, spices and cellophane. These supplies will help Remedios cook and sell more fish. With this, she could now cater other menus and hopefully this could help attract more buyers to come and purchase. She could now provide good food to the whole family.

Remedios hopes that she could improve her current business in order for her to continue to finance the schooling of her youngest child for a brighter future.

loans.use: to buy more supplies like fish, spices and cellophane

loans.name: Sokhim

texts.en: Sokhim is a 32-year-old married garment worker with three young children. She is from Kampong Speu province in Cambodia. She has worked in a factory in a nearby province since 2012.  All of her children attend school and her husband is 35, and a construction worker. Both of them can earn about USD 11 a day. Now Sokhim would like to request a loan to buy bricks, cement and steel to build ground floor rooms. With the loan, she will be able to have more rooms and space for living. In the future, she is going to buy farmland, build fences around her house and support her children to finish high school.

loans.use: to buy bricks, cement and steel to build ground floor rooms.

loans.name: Rolando

texts.en:
This is Rolando, who previously accessed a 15,000 PHP loan to buy more quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. His earnings were a big help in the education of his children and in the family's personal, household and business expenditures.

Rolando is requesting another 18,000 PHP loan to purchase raw ingredients and supplies needed in his business. His profits will definitely help him to sustain his daily needs and the educational expenses of his children. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart. 

Rolando wants to have a bigger place for his business. He desires to become successful and be able to provide the best future possible for his children. He meets up regularly with his co-fellowship members to share stories and also to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for fresh meat and other ingredients for his food stall

loans.name: Eab

texts.en:
From Prey Chhor District, Kampong Cham Province, Eab, 41, is an active and honest rice farmer. She is the mother of two dependent children. Her farmland is located near her house. So far, she has been a farmer for twenty years. She can make an income of USD 2.00 a day, on average.

To accelerate her farming process, she wants to buy cows to help in plowing the land and carrying many heavy farming materials. Because there is insufficient money, she would like to apply for a Kiva loan via HKL to buy cows. She is thankful to all the lenders for their generous behavior.

loans.use: to buy cows

loans.name: He Muong 6 Group

texts.en:
Thoi is a young Thai minority lady who is married and has a small child. She lives happily with her husband and her child in a Thai traditional house, along with her in-laws, and works at agricultural production for a living. Indeed, cultivating rice is the main activity generating income for the family. In addition, to cover living expenses and to have a stable income, she diversifies cultivation and animal husbandry by growing corn, cassava and raising buffalo, pigs and chickens.

To have enough capital for the investment in agricultural production, Thoi has taken out a loan from the Anh Chi Em Program. This is the third time she has received a loan from the Program and she will use it to rent a machine for leveling the field to prepare the land for the next crop. With the financial support and the training and counseling provided by the Program, Thoi believes that she could overcome plenty of difficulties in life and could provide better for her family, especially her small child. In the picture, she stands at the first from the right.

loans.use: to rent a machine for leveling the field to prepare the land for the next crop

loans.name: Channy

texts.en: Channy is a 23-year-old single freshman from Kampong Speu province of Cambodia. Nowadays, he is studying information technology at the university and working in a city.  He has worked as IT staff in a company since 2013, earning $5 a day. Due to a lack of financial support, Channy would like to request a loan to pay his tuition fee for a semester of his first year. With this loan, he will be able to go through the first semester successfully. In the future, he wants to help his parents to renovate their house.

loans.use: to pay his tuition fee for a semester of his first year

loans.name: Andrea

texts.es:
Andrea es de la ciudad de San Lorenzo, ella a la vez que estudia también trabaja, es una persona muy sacrificada que lucha por poder salir adelante.
Está estudiando la carrera de administración de empresas, que le permitirá poder seguir con su meta de ser una profesional exitosa.
Pide este préstamo para poder cubrir sus gastos de tesis, de manera a poder seguir con su trabajo como lo viene haciendo.
texts.en:
Andrea is from San Lorenzo. She is working while attending university. She works very hard to get ahead.  She is studying for a career in business administration, which will enable her to continue working toward her goal of becoming a successful professional.

She is seeking a loan in order to cover the cost of her degree, and she will still continue working as she is doing now.

loans.use: to pay for her degree.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth sends you her thanks for your generosity because her previous loan entrenched her business. She was able to purchase more vegetables and other products needed to increase her product inventory. The loan also helped her provide for the educational expenses of her child and pay for their daily needs.

She is very positive that she could improve her business more if you will lend her an amount of 30,000 PHP. This new loan will go to additional stock of vegetables and other products. Her customers will likely buy more items if she has more of her products displayed in her store. An increase in sales will also result in a significant increase in profit, which will also result in her business becoming viable and sustainable. Simultaneously, she could sustain the needs of her family.

In addition to this, Elizabeth also operates a utility vehicle for transportation service and she wishes to add more units to increase her profit. She dreams that her family will always be healthy and happy. She meets every week with her co-fellowship members* to share stories of her work and to also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for vegetables and other products needed in her business.

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta sends you her thanks for your generosity because her previous loan greatly enriched her business. She was able to buy products and supplies which were needed in her business. The loan also helped her provide for their daily needs and expenditures.

She is very positive that she could improve her business more if you will let her borrow again an amount of 35,000 PHP. This new loan will go to additional merchandise like clothing, footwear, undergarments and cosmetics. Simultaneously, she could sustain the needs of her family with the help of this assistance.

Julieta hopes that her profit from the business will continue to increase. She also desires to save for the future of her family. She meets every week with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and to also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional supplies and merchandise such as clothing, footwear, undergarments and cosmetics needed in her business.

loans.name: Sabari Kadi Group

texts.fr:
Mme MARCELINE représente le groupe SABARI KADI. Elle se porte bien. Elle est mariée et mère de 02 enfants. Le plus âgé a 08ans et le moins âgé a 04ans. 01 va à l’école.
Elle vend des habits depuis  plus de 03ans. Mme s’approvisionne au marché du secteur 10. 
Elle veut s’acheter 05douzaines d’habits, 04pièces de pagnes et 06douzaines d'habits pour enfants.
Mme veut épargner ses  bénéfices. Elle ambitionne toujours ouvrir une boutique de prêt à porter, améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Marceline represents the Sabari Kadi group. She is doing well. She is married and the mother of two children, the elder is eight and the younger four years old. One of them attends school. 
Marceline has been selling clothing for over three years, and buys her stock at the market in sector 10. She wants to buy five dozen dresses, four traditional 'pagne' outfits and six dozen outfits for children.
She wants to put her profits into her savings, and still hopes to open a small store for off-the-peg clothing, and to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy clothing outfits for adults and children.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for school expenses (to catch up and graduate in 2015).

loans.name: Yoy

texts.en:
Yoy, 56 years old, is originally from Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. She is a mother of seven children; two are single and live under her support, while the other five are married and live independently. To make a living, she manages and operates a farming business, primarily growing and selling rice on a small piece of farmland located near her house. This business allows her to earn 4 USD a day, on average. So far, she has been in this business for more than twenty years. 

In this farming season, she is going to use natural fertilizers on her farmland. Because there is a shortage of money, she would like to get a Kiva loan via HKL to buy fertilizers to use in her farming process. With the support of this loan, she hopes that the fertilizers can make her rice grow better and produce more crops for her.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers

loans.name: Nemia

texts.en:
Nemia sends you her thanks for your generosity because her previous loan has strengthened her business. She was able to purchase additional grocery products needed to increase her product inventory. The loan also helped her provide for the educational expense of her children and pay for their daily needs.

She is very positive that she could improve her business more if you would lend her 12,000 PHP. This new loan will go to additional stocks of groceries, toiletries, and beverages. Her customers will likely buy more items if she has more of her products displayed in her store. An increase in sales will significantly increase her profit, which will also result in her business becoming viable and sustainable. Simultaneously, she could meet the needs of her family. Nemia dreams of improving their general living conditions and she wants to expand her business. 

Nemia meets every week with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries, and beverages needed in her general store business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy sand, cement, bricks, iron, and stone.

loans.name: Warna Sari Group

texts.en:
Luh, head of the Warna Sari group, is responsible for the payment to MUK. Luh sold all of her fattening pigs, which she had been raising for six months. She was very pleased with the benefits she got. This is all because of MUK, Kiva and the lenders. She says thanks for the support that she had. The profits, after deductions for payments to MUK, are saved for future needs.

Warna Sari group continues to take out loans. The loan in this period will also used to support their efforts in breeding pigs. Now Luh has a sow. Currently the price of piglets is very expensive, 700,000 IDR per piglet. She will use her portion of the loan to purchase superior feed and renovate the cage for the preparation of newborn piglets. 

She and the members of Warna Sari hope this effort will be advanced and they can become independent in the attempt so they do not need to borrow anymore.

loans.use: to purchase superior feed and renovate her piglets' cage

loans.name: Marga Indah Ternak Group

texts.en:
The Marga Indah Ternak group feels excited. Their business in pig breeding has earned a maximum result. The price for pork now is quite high and they sold their pigs at a good time. All the member earned a satisfactory profit. 

Ni Komang sold all of her pigs. She earned a satisfactory profit. Now she can fullfill her daily needs from this effort.

The Marga Indah Ternak group continues its borrowing. The loan and the pig-breeder program from MUK have proven to improve their lives. They can have a loan without collateral and also receive training for better knowledge of the pig business. 

Ni Komang will use her loans to purchase superior-quality feed. She has many sows now and she must make sure they have good food for their pregnancy. She hopes her piglets can grow faster. She has plans to save all the profit for business capital.

loans.use: to purchase superior-quality feed

loans.name: Dado's Group

texts.fr:
Le groupement a été mise en place le 08 Mai 2009 à l’occasion de son inauguration. Il regroupe en son sein des femmes animées d’un réel désire de développer des activités génératrices de revenu et qui ont une expérience de plus de cinq dans le programme des bancs villageois. Elles vivent dans le même village et entretiennent  de bons rapports de voisinage. Elles ont comme activité principale le petit commerce.

Madame Dado  (assise complètement à droite), est l’emprunteuse vedette du groupe. Elle est âgée de 54 ans est mariée et mère de 03 enfants dont 02 filles et 01 garçon. C’est une femme très entreprenante et s’active dans la vente de produits de consommation plus particulièrement les condiments et légumes : ognons, pomme de terre, bouillons culinaires,… Qu’elle achète en gros au marché central de la commune pour la revente au détail dans son village où elle a un magasin. 

Son nouveau prêt lui permettra d’acheter 03 sacs d’ognons, 02 de pomme de terre, divers tablettes de bouillons culinaires et autres condiments pour la revente au détail.

En plus d’accroître son épargne en vu de recevoir un prêt plus important, les bénéfices lui permettront d’assurer une meilleure prise en charge des besoins familiaux (habillement, santé, scolarité, nourriture).
texts.en:
The group was founded on May 8th 2009, and comprises women with a real desire to develop income generating businesses - who have more than five year's experience with the banc villageois (local credit) programmes.
They live in the same village and maintain good neighbourly relations. Their main activity is retail trading. Dado (seated on the far right in the photo) is the group's highlighted borrower.
She is 54 years old, married and the mother of two girls and one boy. She is a very dynamic woman, and works selling consumable products - notably condiments and vegetables: Onions, potatoes, cooking broths etc, that she buys wholesale from the local central market in order to resell in smaller quantities in her village where she has a store.
Her new loan will allow her to buy three sacks of onions, two sacks of potatoes, various stock cubes and other condiments for retail selling.
As well as growing her savings through getting a larger loan, the profits will allow her to take better control of the family's needs (clothing, health, schooling and nutrition).

loans.use: to buy three sacks of onions, two sacks of potatoes, various stocks and other condiments for retail sale.

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida sends her thanks for her lenders' generosity because her previous loans have greatly enriched her business. She was able to buy essential products needed in her food stall business as well as to provide for her family's daily needs and expenditures.

She is positive that she can further improve her business if she is able to obtain a new loan in the amount of PhP 45,000. This new loan will allow her to buy eggs, crackers, "balut" (fertilized duck eggs), and other food items to offer for sale. The expected profits will allow her to be better able to sustain the needs of her family.

Zenaida wants to become more successful in her business, and she also would like to try her hand at other possible business opportunities as well. 

She meets every week with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work as well as to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to buy eggs, crackers, "balut" (fertilized duck eggs), and other food items to offer for sale

loans.name: Tarcela

texts.en:
Tarcela, a 49-year-old married mother of eight children in Iloilo, Philippines, has been engaged in a fishing business with her husband for more than 15 years now. This is the family's sole source of income.

Tarcela is requesting a loan to buy new fishing nets, lead weights, hooks, etc. With this loan, she and her husband will be able to improve their catch, thus giving them more fish to sell in the market. 

In the future, Tarcela hopes to make their fishing business a greater success.

loans.use: to buy new fishing nets, lead weights, hooks, etc

loans.name: Boldukan

texts.ru: Болдукан, 38 лет, замужем, есть 7 детей, вся семья с радостью помогает по хозяйству. У Болдукан среднее образование. Около 10 лет назад Болдукан стала заниматься животноводством и полеводством, накопив на старт сумму в 15,000 сом (KGS). Благодаря упорному труду Болдукан на сегодняшний день у нее есть 1 корова, 25 овец и 2 лошади. Также на земельной доле мерою 1,18 ГА она выращивает ячмень для внутрихозяйственного потребления. Ежемесячная прибыль составляет всего около 8,000 сом (KGS) в месяц. В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Болдукан обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 40,000 сом (KGS) на покупку овец для откорма и реализации. Болдукан планирует расширить ее бизнес и накопить средства на постройку дома для ее семьи.
texts.en:
Boldukan is 38 years old, married and has seven children. The whole family helps with the farm with pleasure. Boldukan has secondary education. Around 10 years ago, she started working with livestock breeding and field crop cultivation, after having saved up start-up capital of 15,000 som (KGS). 

Thanks to Boldukan's persistent work, she currently has one cow, 25 sheep and two horses. She also grows barley for own use on a plot of land of 1.18 hectares. The total monthly income is around 8,000 som (KGS). 

With an aim to further develop her business, Boldukan turned to the bank "Bai Tushum" for a loan in the amount of 40,000 som (KGS) to purchase sheep to fatten and sell. Boldukan plans to expand her business and save money for building a house for her family.

loans.use: to purchase sheep for fattening and reselling

loans.name: Nurullo

texts.ru: Нурулло  живет в кишлаке Даштикон. Ему 48 лет. Он женат и имеет двоих детей. У Нурулло   среднее специальное   образование.   По профессии он строитель. Животноводством он занимается малых лет. Это приносит дополнительный доход в его семью. В этом ему помогает его семья. Он хочет купить скот для откорма, но у него не хватает собственных средств. Он обратился в МДО Арванд за кредитом. Он надеется на положительный результат. Он заранее благодарит за поддержку и доверие.
texts.en:
Nurullo lives in the village of Dashtikon. He is 48 years old. He is married and has two children. Nurullo has vocational education. He is a builder by profession. He has worked with livestock breeding since his early years. This brings an additional income for his family. His family helps him with this business. 

Nurullo would like to purchase livestock to breed, but he does not have enough own money. He turned to "MDO Arvand" for a loan. He hopes for a positive result and thanks for the support and faith in advance.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy fabric and thread.

loans.name: Kuña Guapa Group

texts.es:
El comité “Kuña Guapa” se formo en la ciudad de Lambaré, son  27 señoras,  poseen  diversas actividades comerciales, pero también hacen actividades juntas que fortalecen su compañerismo. Es un grupo que sabe trabajar en equipo y se comprometen en cada actividad que realizan.
Maricarmen integra este grupo, es una mujer  muy sacrificada y luchadora, que se esfuerza para poder crecer y salir adelante, tiene un negocio modesto que con mucho sacrificio pudo montar y hacer crecer. Tiene una peluquería y comenta que por medio de su negocio está creciendo y saliendo adelante, y comenta que su meta es poder seguir creciendo y dar fuentes de trabajos a otras personas.
Pide este préstamo para poder comprar shampoo, enjuagues, cremas, tintes, y demás, de manera a poder seguir dando un buen servicio a sus clientes.
texts.en:
The “Kuña Guapa” committee was set up in the city of Lambaré. It is made up of 27 women who operate diverse businesses, but who also organize activities together to reinforce their team spirit. This group knows how to work as a team and gives 100% in all the activities they undertake. 

Maricarmen is a member of this group. She is a very self-sacrificing and tenacious woman, who works hard to grow and make a living. She has a modest business that required a lot of sacrifice for her to set up and develop. 

She has a beauty salon and says that it allows her to develop and make a living. She adds that her goal is to continue to expand and be able to offer work to other people. 

She is requesting this loan to buy shampoo, conditioner, creams, hair dyes, and other products so she can continue offering good service to her clients.

loans.use: to buy shampoo, conditioner, creams, hair dyes, and other products.

loans.name: Aissatou's Group

texts.fr:
Le groupement a été mise en place le 08 Mai 2009 à l’occasion de son inauguration. Il regroupe en son sein des femmes animées d’un réel désire de développer des activités génératrices de revenu et qui ont une expérience de plus de cinq dans le programme des bancs villageois. Elles vivent dans le même village et entretiennent  de bons rapports de voisinage. Elles ont comme activité principale le petit commerce.

Madame Aissatou (assise à la troisième position de la droite vers la gauche), est l’emprunteuse vedette du groupe. Elle est mariée, âgée de 33 ans et mère de 03 enfants dont 02 garçons et 01 fille. Son activité s’inscrit dans la vente de denrées alimentaires qu’elle achète au marché hebdomadaire de la sous région pour la revente au détail. Elle jouit d’une bonne expérience dans ce domaine.

Avec son nouveau prêt, elle compte acheter 05 sacs de sucre, des paquets de thé vert et un sac d’ognon pour la revente au détail.

Avec les bénéfices, elle compte accroître son épargne et aider son mari dans la prise en charge des besoins de la famille : nourriture, scolarité et santé.
texts.en:
The group was founded on May 8th 2009, and comprises women with a real desire to develop income generating businesses - who have more than five year's experience with the banc villageois (local credit) programmes.
They live in the same village and maintain good neighbourly relations. Their main activity is retail trading. 

Aissatou (seated third from the right in the photo) is the group's highlighted borrower.
She is 33 years old, married and the mother of two boys and one girl. Her business is selling foodstuffs that she buys at the sub-district's weekly market in order to resell retail. She has good experience in this business.

With this new loan she intends to buy five bags of sugar, packets of green tea and a bag of onions for reselling in smaller quantities.

With her profits, she plans to grow her savings and to help her husband with funding the family's needs : food, schooling and healthcare.

loans.use: to buy five bags of sugar, packets of green tea and a bag of onions - for retail selling.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy sacks of charcoal to sell at retail and wholesale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase fabric for sewing women's dresses for selling

loans.name: Jenel

texts.en:
Jenel, age 28, is engaged in a fishing business along with her husband. They have three children. Fishing is the family's main source of income, and the couple has been engaged in this business for several years now.

Jenel is asking for a loan in order to buy new fishing nets, lead weights, and a boat engine. This loan will help Jenel and her husband improve their catch, which in turn will allow them to sell more fish in the market.

In the future, Jenel hopes to make her business a success. Moreover, she wants to save money for her children's schooling.

loans.use: to buy new fishing nets, lead weights, and a boat engine

loans.name: Amado

texts.es: Amado, tiene la edad  de 47 años, está en unión libre, vive con su señora. Con su crédito pretende hacer la compra de herramientas y equipo que utiliza en la construcción de viviendas y otros tipos de estructuras, con la compra de estas herramientas espera ser más eficiente y realizar los trabajos de la mejor manera y con una calidad mas alta, además de agilizar las obras. La idea es aprovechar el conocimiento que a tenido a lo largo de los años trabajando en este campo y con las mejoras en sus técnicas espera aumentar la demanda en trabajo. Con esta compra podrá desarrollar con más facilidad los trabajos, y a la vez tener un ahorro que le permitirá ir teniendo más herramientas e invertir más en su actividad.  Es el primer  préstamo que  ha recibido de FUDECOSUR. Él no había tenido antes otros préstamos en bancos estatales, pero FUDECOSUR le ha brindado el préstamo con mayores facilidades y la tasa de intereses mucho más baja.
texts.en:
Amado is 47 years old and is married.  With this loan he will purchase the tools and equipment he needs for building houses and other types of structures. With the purchase of these tools he hopes to be more efficient and ensure his projects are completed with the highest quality while being completed faster.  

The idea is to use the knowledge he has acquired over the years working in this field and technical improvements in order to increase the demand for his work.  With this purchase he will be able to easily increase his projects and at the same time have more tools and invest more in his business.

This is his first loan from FUDECOSUR. He hasn't had other loans from state banks, but FUDECOSUR has provided this loan with better terms and a lower interest rate.

loans.use: to buy construction tools.

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalia operates a sari-sari (general store) business in the town of Dulag, Leyte. She is the industrious mother of four children, the youngest of whom is 15 years old. In her store, she sells basic commodities like canned goods, noodles, biscuits, soft drinks, and beverages. She has been operating her store for more than 20 years now.

Amalia is asking for a loan in the amount of PhP 20,000 in order to buy supplies for the store, such as toiletries, noodles, canned goods, and seasonings. These supplies will allow her to keep her store well-stocked as well as to provide a greater variety of products, thereby attracting more customers and improving her sales.

In the future, Amalia hopes to improve her business in order to continue to finance the schooling of her children.

loans.use: to buy items such as toiletries, canned goods, noodles, and seasonings to offer for sale

loans.name: Ramiro

texts.es:
Ramiro, es soltero y no tiene hijos, vive en la casa de sus padres en la zona Pasankeri en la ciudad de La Paz.
El trabaja como empleado más de ocho horas en una empresa privada, y por las noches estudia en la universidad; es por eso que solicita el crédito para pagar un curso de operador de equipo pesado, Ramiro esta convencido de aportar para la casa pero necesita mas ayuda en cuanto a su educación. Ramiro goza de buena salud y esta convencido de poder hacer todo lo que se ha propuesto
texts.en:
Ramiro is single and doesn’t have children. He lives with his parents in the Pasankeri area in the city of La Paz.
